Sense.DEF: ordinary or usual
Sense.EXAMPLE: general cooking and cleaning
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般的做饭和清洁工作
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hate paperwork as a general rule.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般情况下我是讨厌做文案工作的。

Sense.DEF: shared by or affecting most people, or most of the people in a group
Sense.EXAMPLE: These courses are based around topics of general interest.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些课程的内容是大家普遍感兴趣的话题。
Sense.EXAMPLE: How soon can the drug be made available for general use?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种药要多久才能被广泛使用？

Sense.DEF: not limited to one use, activity, subject etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔用途﹑活动﹑主题等〕广泛的﹐综合的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The next ten minutes passed in general conversation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 接下来的十分钟里大家就随便交谈。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a good general fertilizer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是一种很有效的多用途肥料。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Watford General Hospital
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 沃特福德综合医院
Sense.EXAMPLE: This type of microphone is suitable for general use.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种麦克风用途很广。

Sense.DEF: used to talk about an approximate area or direction
Sense.EXAMPLE: Pat and his friend were in the general area of the crime when it happened.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 案发时帕特和他的朋友就在附近。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They started walking in the general direction of the pub.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们开始朝酒吧的大致方向走去。

Sense.DEF: used in the name of a job to show that the person who does it has complete responsibility
Sense.EXAMPLE: the general manager
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总经理
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Attorney General
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总检察长﹐司法部长

Sense.DEF: an officer of very high rank in the army or air force
a medicine that makes you unconscious during an operation so that you do not feel any pain
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had the operation done under general anaesthetic.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我是全身麻醉后接受手术的。

Sense.DEF: the legal officer of a US company with the highest rank
Sense.TRAN: 〔美国公司中的〕首席律师[法律顾问]

Sense.DEF: a firm of US lawyers that gives general legal advice
a post office department that keeps someone’s letters until that person comes to get them
an election in which all the people in a country who can vote elect a government
Sense.EXAMPLE: during the 1987 general election campaign
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 1987年大选竞选期间
Sense.EXAMPLE: an attempt to persuade the government to hold a general election have a general election
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 说服政府举行大选的努力

Sense.DEF: the place from which the actions of an organization, especially a military one, are controlled
a British spelling of generalize
a person who knows about many different things and can do many things well
a very general statement that avoids mentioning details or specific cases
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Secretary of State has given us nothing today but bland generalities.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 国务卿今天只对我们讲了几句乏味的空话。

Sense.DEF: most of a group of people or things
Sense.TRAN: 某群体中大多数的人[物]
Sense.EXAMPLE: Temporary workers are considerably younger than the generality of workers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 临时工比大多数工人年轻不少。

Sense.DEF: the quality of being true or useful in most situations
a statement about all the members of a group that may be true in some or many situations but is not true in every case
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can’t make generalizations about what men and women are like.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 男人什么样﹐女人什么样﹐不能一概而论。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a sweeping generalization based on speculation
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 靠猜测得出的笼统概括

Sense.DEF: the act of making generalizations
to form a general principle or opinion after considering only a small number of facts or examples

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She has a tendency to generalize from her husband to all men.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她总爱把自己对丈夫的看法推及所有的男人。

Sense.DEF: to make a general statement about the whole of a group or thing

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It is difficult to generalise about the kind of people who come on these courses.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 很难笼统地说参加这些课程的都是什么类型的人。

Sense.DEF: to say that an idea, result etc is related to a larger group
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can we generalise this principle?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个原理可以推而广之吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can the research findings be generalized to a wider population?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个研究的结果适用于更广泛的人群吗？

Sense.DEF: involving or relating to many things, people, or parts
Sense.TRAN: 笼统的﹔普遍的﹔概括性的
Sense.EXAMPLE: generalized statements
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 概括性的陈述
Sense.EXAMPLE: generalized anxiety
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 普遍的焦虑

Sense.DEF: knowledge of facts about many different subjects
Sense.EXAMPLE: a general knowledge quiz
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 常识问答比赛

Sense.DEF: considering or relating to the whole of a thing or group, rather than to details or specific cases or parts
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was generally a positive conversation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总的来说﹐这是一次积极的谈话。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s not really ill, just generally run-down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她并不是真的生病﹐只是感到全身疲惫。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Generally, part-timers work in low-status, low-wage occupations.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 总体上看﹐兼职人员从事的是低级﹑低薪的工作。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The second survey was concerned with working-class culture more generally.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二次调查涉及更广泛的工薪阶层的文化。

Sense.DEF: by or to most people

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The plants are generally regarded as weeds.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些植物一般都被当作杂草。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a generally accepted view
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个被普遍接受的观点

Sense.EXAMPLE: It could be five years before the drug is generally available.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种药可能还要过五年才能广泛投入市场。

Sense.DEF: usually or most of the time
Sense.EXAMPLE: I generally get in to work by 8.00.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我通常8点钟之前就来上班。

Sense.DEF: used to introduce a statement that is true in most cases but not always
Sense.EXAMPLE: Generally speaking, the more expensive the stereo, the better it is.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般说来﹐立体声音响越贵的越好。

Sense.DEF: the work of a doctor or lawyer who deals with all the ordinary types of illnesses or legal cases, rather than one specific type
Sense.TRAN: 全科医生[普通律师]的工作

Sense.DEF: a group of lawyers or doctors who do all types of work
Sense.TRAN: 普通律师事务所﹔全科诊所

Sense.DEF: a doctor who is trained in general medicine

Sense.GRAMTRAN: 英国英语中亦用复数动词
Sense.DEF: the ordinary people in a country, rather than people belonging to a particular group
Sense.EXAMPLE: health education aimed at the general public
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 针对老百姓的健康教育

Sense.DEF: suitable for most situations or jobs, or having a wide range of uses
Sense.EXAMPLE: a general-purpose computer
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一台通用计算机

Sense.DEF: the skill or position of being a general
Sense.TRAN: 将军的指挥才能﹐将才﹔将军职衔

Sense.DEF: the group of military officers who work for a military leader
Sense.TRAN: 参谋部〔指全体军事参谋〕

Sense.DEF: a shop that sells a wide variety of goods, especially one in a small town
a situation when most of the workers in a country refuse to work in order to protest about working conditions, wages etc
to produce or cause something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a useful technique for generating new ideas
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 能产生新创意的有用技术
Sense.EXAMPLE: The program would generate a lot of new jobs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个项目将创造许多新的就业岗位。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Tourism generates income for local communities.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅游业为当地社区创造了收益。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The project generated enormous interest.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个项目引起了人们极大的兴趣。

Sense.DEF: to produce heat, electricity, or another form of energy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Wind turbines generate electricity for the local community.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 风力机为当地社区发电。

Sense.GRAMTRAN: 英国英语中亦用复数动词
Sense.DEF: all people of about the same age
Sense.EXAMPLE: Like most of my generation, I had never known a war.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 和我们这一代的大多数人一样﹐我并没有经历过战争。
Sense.EXAMPLE: In my generation the divorce rate is very high.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们这一代人离婚率很高。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the need to preserve the planet for future generations
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 为子孙后代保护地球的必要性

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the post-war generation of writers
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 战后的一代作家

GramExa.GLOSS: the younger or older people in society
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The younger generation don’t know what hard work is.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 年轻一代不知道什么叫艰苦的劳动。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The story has been handed down from generation to generation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个故事是一代一代传下来的。

Sense.DEF: all the members of a family of about the same age
Sense.EXAMPLE: Friction is common when three generations live together.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 三代同堂﹐摩擦是难免的。

GramExa.GLOSS: being a member of the first, second etc generation to live or be born in a country
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 第一代/第二代等〔指生活或出生在某国的人〕
GramExa.EXAMPLE: first-generation immigrants
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 第一代移民
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a third-generation American
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 第三代美国人

Sense.DEF: the average period of time between the birth of a person and the birth of that person’s children
Sense.TRAN: 一代人的时间〔指一个人的出生与其孩子出生之间的平均时间〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Some families have lived here for generations.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些人家祖祖辈辈都住在这里。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The country’s attitude toward government is harsher than it was a generation ago.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在国人对政府的态度比前一代人批判性更强了。

Sense.DEF: a group of things that were developed from something else, or from which better things were developed

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the new generation of mobile phones
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 新一代的手机

Sense.EXAMPLE: the first generation of nuclear power stations
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 第一代核电站

GramExa.EXAMPLE: second-generation computers
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 第二代计算机

Sense.DEF: the process of producing something or making something happen

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the generation of electricity
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 发电

Sense.DEF: people born and living in the US, whose parents originally come from a foreign country and have not learnt to speak English properly. Generation 1.5 children are able to speak English well, but talk in the language spoken by their parents when they are at home.
Sense.TRAN: 第1.5代〔指父母移居自国外﹑说不好英语﹐自己在美国出生成长﹑英语流利﹑在家却说父母的母语的一代人〕

Sense.DEF: connected with a particular generation or the relationship between different generations
Sense.EXAMPLE: generational conflict
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两代人之间的冲突
Sense.EXAMPLE: generational divisions
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两代人之间的分歧

Sense.DEF: the lack of understanding or the differences between older people and younger people
the group of people who were born during the late 1960s and the 1970s in the US
Sense.TRAN: X一代〔指美国20世纪60年代后期及70年代出生的一代人〕

Sense.DEF: the group of people who were born during the 1980s and 1990s in the US
Sense.TRAN: Y一代〔指美国20世纪80年代及90年代出生的一代人〕

Sense.DEF: able to produce something
Sense.TRAN: 有生产能力的﹐能生产的
Sense.EXAMPLE: the generative power of the life force
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生命力的生成能力

Sense.DEF: the description of a language using rules that produce all the possible correct sentences of the language
Sense.TRAN: 生成语法/语言学/音系学

Sense.DEF: a machine that produces electricity
Sense.EXAMPLE: an emergency generator
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 应急发电机

Sense.DEF: a company that produces electricity
something that produces something else

GramExa.EXAMPLE: good generators of income
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 很好的收入来源

Sense.DEF: relating to a whole group of things rather than to one thing

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Fine Arts is a generic term for subjects such as painting, music and sculpture.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 艺术是绘画﹑音乐﹑雕塑等学科的通称。

Sense.DEF: a generic product does not have a special name to show that it is made by a particular company
a generous attitude, or generous behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLE: an act of great generosity
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 十分慷慨的行为

GramExa.EXAMPLE: his generosity to the poor
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他对穷人的慷慨

Sense.EXAMPLE: I shall never forget the generosity shownby the people of Bastaisk.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我永远也不会忘记巴斯泰斯克人的慷慨大方。

Sense.DEF: someone who is generous is willing to give money, spend time etc, in order to help people or give them pleasure

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She’s always very generous to the kids.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她对小孩总是很大方。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Jim is very generous with his time.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉姆很不吝惜他的时间。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It was generous of them to ask Anna along.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们邀请安娜一起去﹐真是大方。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: my employer’s generous offer to pay the bill
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我老板要求付账的慷慨提议

Sense.DEF: larger or more than the usual size or amount
Sense.TRAN: 大量的﹐丰富的〔指超出通常的规格或数量〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a generous glass of wine
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一大杯葡萄酒

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a generous helping of pasta
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一大份意大利面

Sense.EXAMPLE: He had a well-shaped generous mouth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的嘴宽而有型。

Sense.DEF: sympathetic in the way you deal with people, and tending to see the good qualities in someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was generous enough to overlook my little mistake.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她非常宽宏大量﹐不计较我的小过失。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: Please give generously to the refugee fund.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 请为难民基金慷慨解囊。

Sense.DEF: the beginning or origin of something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the genesis of the myth
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个神话故事的起源

Sense.DEF: a way of treating certain diseases by using genetic engineering
relating to genes or genetics
Sense.EXAMPLE: genetic defects
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 遗传性缺陷
Sense.EXAMPLE: each person’s genetic make-up
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每个人的遗传特征
Sense.EXAMPLE: genetic research
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 基因研究

Sense.DEF: genetically modified foods or plants have had their genetic structure changed so that they are not affected by particular diseases or harmful insects
Sense.TRAN: 〔食物或植物〕转基因的﹐基因改造的

Sense.DEF: the arrangement of genes that controls the way a living thing develops
the science of changing the genetic structure of an animal, plant, or human, usually to make them stronger or healthier
the process of examining the pattern of someone’s genes, especially in order to find out if they are guilty of a crime
Sense.TRAN: 基因指纹分析〔尤用于犯罪鉴定〕

Sense.DEF: the study of how the qualities of living things are passed on in their genes
friendly and happy
Sense.EXAMPLE: a genial smile
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 亲切的微笑

Sense.DEF: a magical creature in old Arabian stories that will do what you want when you call it
Sense.TRAN: 〔古代阿拉伯故事中的〕精灵﹐妖怪

Sense.LEXUNIT: let the genie out of the bottle
Sense.DEF: to do something that has a great and often bad effect on a situation, which can then never return to its previous state
Sense.TRAN: 把精灵放出魔瓶〔指做某事造成了无法挽回的严重后果〕

Sense.DEF: relating to or affecting the outer sex organs
Sense.EXAMPLE: the genital area
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 外阴部
Sense.EXAMPLE: genital mutilation
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 外生殖器切割

Sense.DEF: the outer sex organs
a form of a noun in some languages which shows a relationship of possession or origin between one thing and another
Sense.TRAN: 〔某些语言中名词的〕属格﹐所有格

Sense.DEF: a very high level of intelligence, mental skill, or ability, which only a few people have
Sense.EXAMPLE: The film reveals Fellini’s genius.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部影片展现了费里尼的天赋。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Wynford was an architect of genius.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 温福德是一名天才建筑师。

GramExa.GLOSS: a very clever idea
GramExa.EXAMPLE: At the time, his appointment seemed a stroke of genius.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 当时﹐他的任命似乎是一个高明之举。

Sense.EXAMPLE: a work of pure genius
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 天才之作

Sense.DEF: someone who has an unusually high level of intelligence, mental skill, or ability
Sense.EXAMPLE: Freud was a genius.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 弗洛伊德是个天才。

GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 音乐/喜剧/数学等天才

GramExa.EXAMPLE: My father was a genius at storytelling.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我父亲是个讲故事的天才。

Sense.DEF: special skill at doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: That woman has a genius for organization.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个女人的组织能力超乎常人。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Warhol’s genius for publicity
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 沃霍尔的宣传天才

Sense.DEF: the deliberate murder of a whole group or race of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: The military leaders were accused of genocide.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 军方领导人被指控实施种族大屠杀。

Sense.DEF:
all the
genes
in one type of living thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: the human genome
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 人类基因组

Sense.DEF:
relating to all the
genes that are found in one type of living thing

the study of
genomes

the
genetic
nature of one type of living thing
a particular type of art, writing, music etc, which has certain features that all examples of this type share
Sense.TRAN: 〔艺术﹑写作﹑音乐等的〕类型﹐体裁

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a new genre of film-making
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一种新的电影摄制体裁

Sense.EXAMPLE: a literary genre
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 文学体裁

Sense.DEF:
a
gentleman
Sense.EXAMPLE: a well-dressed elderly gent
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位衣着体面的老先生
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve always prided myself on being a perfect gent.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一向为身为一名体面绅士而自豪。

Sense.DEF: a public toilet for men
polite, gentle, or graceful
Sense.TRAN: 彬彬有礼的﹐斯文的﹐文雅的
Sense.EXAMPLE: She broke into a genteel run.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她优雅地跑了起来。

Sense.DEF: from or relating to a good social class
a small plant with blue or purple flowers that grows in mountain areas
someone who is not Jewish
the quality of being polite, gentle, or graceful, and of seeming to belong to a high social class
Sense.TRAN: 彬彬有礼﹐斯文﹐文雅﹔高贵气派
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hotel had an air of discreet gentility.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家酒店有一种不露痕迹的典雅气派。

Sense.DEF: kind and careful in the way you behave or do things, so that you do not hurt or damage anyone or anything
Sense.TRAN: 和蔼友善的﹐温和的﹐温柔的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Arthur was a very gentle, caring person.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 阿瑟是一个非常温柔体贴的人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: ‘Where does it hurt?’ she asked in a gentle voice.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: “哪里痛？”她柔声问道。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Be gentle with the baby.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对宝宝动作要轻一些。

Sense.DEF: not extreme, strong, or violent

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a program of regular gentle exercise
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 定期进行舒缓运动的锻炼计划

Sense.EXAMPLE: the gentle pressure of Jill’s hand
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉尔的手轻轻的挤压
Sense.EXAMPLE: After a little gentle persuasion , she agreed to go back to her family.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经过几句温和的劝说﹐她同意回到家里去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Melt the butter over a gentle heat low heat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用文火把黄油化开。

Sense.DEF: a gentle wind or rain is soft and light
Sense.EXAMPLE: a gentle breeze
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 和风

Sense.DEF: a gentle hill or slope is not steep or sharp
Sense.EXAMPLE: the gentle slopes of Mt Pelée
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 培雷山的缓坡

Sense.DEF: people belonging to the higher social classes
a polite word for a man, used especially when talking to or about a man you do not know
Sense.TRAN: 先生〔对男士客气的称呼﹐尤用于不认识的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Could you serve this gentleman please, Miss Bath?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 巴思小姐﹐请你接待一下这位先生好吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 早上好﹐女士们﹐先生们。
Sense.EXAMPLE: An elderly gentleman was asleep next to the fire.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位老先生在火炉旁边睡着了。

Sense.DEF: a man who is always polite, has good manners, and treats other people well
Sense.EXAMPLE: Martin – always the perfect gentleman – got to his feet when my mother walked in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马丁在我母亲进来时站了起来——他一向是十足的绅士派头。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mr Field was a real gentleman .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 菲尔德先生是位真正的君子。

Sense.DEF: a man from a high social class, especially one whose family owns a lot of property
Sense.EXAMPLE: an English country gentleman
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 英国乡绅

Sense.DEF: a man belonging to a high social class who owns and runs a farm, but who usually hires people to do the work
Sense.TRAN: 〔拥有农场但雇人干活的〕乡绅

Sense.DEF: a man who is gentlemanly speaks and behaves politely, and treats other people with respect
Sense.TRAN: 有礼貌的﹐绅士派头的﹐绅士风度的

Sense.DEF: an agreement that is not written down, made between people who trust each other
Sense.TRAN: 〔非书面的﹑以信任为基础的〕君子协定

Sense.DEF: a woman who belongs to a high social class
in a gentle way
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘You go back to bed now,’ he said gently.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你回去睡觉吧。”他温柔地说道。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She kissed me gently on the cheek.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她温柔地亲吻我的脸颊。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gently cook the peppers for 10-15 minutes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用文火将辣椒煮10到15分钟。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rain pattered gently on the roof above.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 雨点轻轻拍打着上面的屋顶。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The road curved gently upwards.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 路缓缓地蜿蜒而上。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to be careful when they are handling something, moving something etc
Sense.TRAN: 小心点！〔用于提醒某人拿或移动某物时当心〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gently, Sammy, you don’t want to break it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小心点﹐萨米﹐别把它打破了。

Sense.DEF: a gradual process in which an area in bad condition where poor people live is changed by people with more money coming to live there and improving it
Sense.TRAN: 地区贵族化﹐旧区改造〔指破败地区因为有富人迁来居住而发生变化〕

Sense.DEF: people who belong to a high social class
Sense.TRAN: 上流社会人士﹐绅士阶层
Sense.EXAMPLE: a member of the landed gentry gentry who own land
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地主乡绅中的一员

Sense.DEF: to bend one or both knees when in church or a holy place as a sign of respect
to show too much respect towards someone or something – used to show disapproval

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was a man of principle, refusing to genuflect to the party leadership.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是一个有原则的人﹐不愿意对党派领导人卑躬屈膝。

Sense.DEF: a genuine feeling, desire etc is one that you really feel, not one you pretend to feel

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The reforms are motivated by a genuine concern for the disabled.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些改革是出自对残疾人真切的关心。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a genuine fear of invasion
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对入侵的真实恐惧

Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Did he really?’ Her surprise seemed genuine.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “他真的这样？”她好像是真的惊讶。

Sense.DEF: something genuine really is what it seems to be
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need laws that will protect genuine refugees.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要有法律来保护真正的难民。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The strap is genuine leather.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这带子是真皮的。

Sense.DEF: someone who is genuine is honest and friendly and you feel you can trust them
Sense.EXAMPLE: She is the most genuine person I’ve ever met.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是我见过的最真诚的人。

Subsense.DEF: a person or thing that is a true example of their type
Subsense.EXAMPLE: If you want to meet a real Southerner, Jake is the genuine article.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你想认识真正的南方人﹐杰克就是货真价实的一位。

Subsense.DEF: something that is real and is not a copy intended to deceive people
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Some fake designer clothes are so good that people have no idea they’re not buying the genuine article.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些假的名牌衣服做得太好了﹐人们根本就不知道自己买的不是真品。

RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 那男孩好像是真的感兴趣。

Exponent.DEF: used about a feeling, thing, or person that really is what they seem to be
Exponent.TRAN: 〔感情﹑物品﹑身份等〕真正的﹐真实的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: genuine concern
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 真切的关心
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Experts believe that the painting is genuine.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 专家们认为此画作是真迹。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: genuine refugees
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 真正的难民

Exponent.DEF: not false or artificial
Exponent.EXAMPLE: real wood
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 实木
Exponent.EXAMPLE: His real name is Reginald.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的真名叫雷金纳德。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It looks just like the real thing .
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 它看上去就和真品一个样。

Exponent.DEF: authentic food, music, clothes etc are correct for the place or the period in history that they are supposed to be from
Exponent.EXAMPLE: It’s a friendly restaurant offering authentic Greek food.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那是一家气氛轻松的餐馆﹐提供正宗的希腊菜肴。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: authentic medieval instruments
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 正宗的中世纪乐器

Exponent.DEF: having all the qualities you would expect a particular type of person or thing to have
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a true friend
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 真正的朋友
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She is a true professional.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是一位名副其实的专家。

Exponent.DEF: bona fide people or things are really what they say they are, especially when this can be checked by looking at official documents
Exponent.TRAN: 真实的〔尤指可通过官方文件核实的〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a bona fide medical qualification
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 真实的医生资格
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a bona fide company
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 合法的公司

Exponent.DEF: evidence or facts that are genuine and can be proved
Exponent.EXAMPLE: There was no hard evidence to support the theory.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 缺乏确凿的证据来支持这一理论。

Sense.DEF:
one of the groups into which scientists divide animals or plants, in which the animals or plants are closely related but cannot produce babies together. A genus includes fewer members than a
family
and more members than a
species
.
relating to the Earth or its surface
Sense.EXAMPLE: geophysics
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地球物理学
Sense.EXAMPLE: geopolitical
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地缘政治学的

Sense.DEF: having a shape or structure made from small flat pieces, usually triangles or pentagons, that are put together to form curves
Sense.TRAN: 网格式的〔指立体形状或结构由小的平面形状构成的〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a geodesic dome
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 网格穹顶

Sense.DEF: someone who has studied geography to a high level
Sense.TRAN: 地理学家﹐地理学研究者

Sense.DEF: relating to the place in an area, country etc where something or someone is

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a large geographical area
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一大片地理区域

Sense.EXAMPLE: their geographical proximity to Japan nearness to Japan
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 它们和日本相邻的地理位置

Sense.DEF: relating to geography
Sense.EXAMPLE: geographical research work
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地理学的研究工作

Sense.DEF: the study of the countries, oceans, rivers, mountains, cities etc of the world
Sense.EXAMPLE: a geography lesson
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地理课

Sense.DEF: the geography of a building, city etc is the way all its parts are arranged

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The geography of the flats made it hard to get to know our neighbours.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公寓的布局使得我们邻里之间很难认识。

Sense.DEF: the study of the rocks, soil etc that make up the Earth, and of the way they have changed since the Earth was formed
an expert in geomancy
the belief that arranging your home, house, office etc in a particular way will bring you good or bad luck

having or using the shapes and lines in
geometry
, such as circles or squares, especially when these are arranged in regular patterns
Sense.EXAMPLE: a geometric design
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 几何图形设计

Sense.DEF:
relating to
geometry
a set of numbers in order, in which each is multiplied by a specific number to produce the next number in the series (as in 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ...)

the study in
mathematics
of the angles and shapes formed by the relationships of lines, surfaces, and solid objects in space
the study of the movements of parts of the Earth, and the forces involved with this, including the weather, the oceans etc
ideas and activities relating to the way that a country’s position, population etc affect its political development and its relationship with other countries, or the study of this
Sense.TRAN: 地理政治学﹐地缘政治学

Sense.DEF: someone from Tyneside in northeast England
Sense.TRAN: 〔英格兰东北部的〕泰恩赛德人

Sense.DEF: a way of speaking that is typical of people from Tyneside
Georgian buildings, furniture etc come from the 18th century, when Britain was ruled by the Kings George I, George II, and George III
Sense.TRAN: 〔英国18世纪〕乔治一世至三世时期风格的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Georgian townhouse
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔治时期风格的市镇住宅

Sense.DEF:
if something such as a
satellite
is in geostationary orbit, it is moving around the Earth in a way that means it stays above the same point on the Earth’s surface
relating to or coming from the heat inside the Earth
Sense.EXAMPLE: a geothermal energy plant
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 地热能工厂

Sense.DEF: a plant with red, pink, or white flowers and round leaves
a small animal with fur, a tail, and long back legs, that is often kept as a pet
relating to the medical care and treatment of old people
Sense.TRAN: 老年医学的﹐老年病学的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a specialist in geriatric medicine
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老年科专家

Sense.DEF: too old to work well
Sense.EXAMPLE: a geriatric rock star
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一位老迈的摇滚乐明星

Sense.DEF: the medical treatment and care of old people
a very small living thing that can make you ill
Sense.EXAMPLE: Put disinfectant down the toilet to kill any germs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在抽水马桶里投放消毒剂杀菌。

Sense.LEXUNIT: the germ of an idea/theory/feeling etc
Sense.DEF: the early stage of an idea, feeling etc that may develop into something bigger and more important
Sense.TRAN: 观念/理论/感情等的萌芽
Sense.EXAMPLE: The germ of a story began to form in his mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个故事开始在他的头脑里成形。

Sense.DEF: the part of a plant or animal that can develop into a new plant or animal
Sense.EXAMPLE: germ cells containing DNA
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 含DNA的生殖细胞

Sense.DEF: relating to Germany, its people, or its language
Sense.TRAN: 德国的﹔德国人的﹔德语的
Sense.EXAMPLE: German history
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 德国历史

Sense.DEF: someone from Germany
the language used in Germany, Austria, and parts of Switzerland
an idea, remark etc that is germane to something is related to it in an important and suitable way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an article which is germane to the subject being discussed
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 和正在讨论的话题密切相关的一篇文章

Sense.DEF: relating to the language family that includes German, Dutch, Swedish, and English
Sense.TRAN: 日耳曼语族的〔包括德语﹑荷兰语﹑瑞典语和英语〕

Sense.DEF: relating to or typical of Germany or German people
an infectious disease that causes red spots on your body, and can damage an unborn child

a large dog rather like a
wolf
that is often used by the police, for guarding property etc
Sense.TRAN: 德国牧羊犬﹐阿尔萨斯狼狗

Sense.DEF: if a seed germinates, or if it is germinated, it begins to grow
if an idea, feeling etc germinates, it begins to develop
Sense.EXAMPLE: The idea of setting up his own company began to germinate in his mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他萌生了自己开公司的想法。

Sense.DEF:
the use of harmful
bacteria
in war to cause illness and death among the enemy
the scientific study of old age and its effects on the body
when politicians change the size and borders of an area before an election, so that one person, group, or party has an unfair advantage
Sense.TRAN: 〔为使某方在选举中占优而进行的〕不公正的选区重新划分

Sense.DEF:
a noun in the form of the
present participle
of a verb, for example ‘shopping’ in the sentence ‘I like shopping’
a whole thing that is different from all its parts, and has qualities that are not present in any of its parts by themselves
Sense.TRAN: 格式塔﹐完形〔一个整体﹐不同于各个组成部分的相加﹐而是具有独立部分所没有的特性〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: gestalt psychology
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 格式塔心理学

Sense.DEF: the secret police force used by the state in Germany during the Nazi period
Sense.TRAN: 盖世太保〔纳粹德国的秘密警察〕

Sense.DEF: the process by which a child or young animal develops inside its mother’s body before birth, or the period of time when this happens
Sense.EXAMPLE: The gestation period of a horse is about 11 months.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 马的妊娠期为11个月左右。

Sense.DEF: the process by which a new idea, piece of work etc is developed, or the period of time when this happens
Sense.TRAN: 〔新的思想﹑作品等的〕构思﹐酝酿﹐孕育

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The report was a very long time in gestation.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这份报告酝酿了很长时间。

Sense.DEF: to make movements with your arms and hands, usually while speaking, because you are excited, angry, or cannot think of the right words to use
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jane gesticulated wildly and shouted ‘Stop! Stop!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 简拼命打着手势﹐喊着“停下！停下！”

Sense.DEF: a movement of part of your body, especially your hands or head, to show what you mean or how you feel

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Jim raised his hands in a despairing gesture.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉姆举起双手﹐做出绝望的手势。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Luke made an obscene gesture with his finger.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卢克用手指做了一个下流的手势。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She shook her head with a gesture of impatience.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不耐烦地摇了摇头。

Sense.DEF: something that you say or do, often something small, to show how you feel about someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: They decided it would be a nice gesture to send her a card.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们认为给她寄一张卡片会是一种友好的表示。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tearing up the price list was simply a symbolic gesture .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 撕碎价格表只是一种象征性的表示。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: As a gesture of goodwill , we have decided to waive the charges on this occasion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次我们已经决定撤诉﹐以示友好。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The Queen has now made a gesture towards public opinion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 女王现在摆出了尊重民意的姿态。

Sense.DEF: to move your hand, arm, or head to tell someone something, or show them what you mean

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Brad gestured towards the door. ‘Get out.’
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 布拉德指着门口说﹕“出去。”

GramExa.PROPFORM: gesture for sb to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He gestured for her to take a seat.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他示意她坐下。

Sense.DEF:
used to wish someone good health when they have just
sneezed
Sense.TRAN: 祝你健康〔对打喷嚏者的祝愿〕

Sense.DEF: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
Sense.EXAMPLE: She got loads of presents.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她收到了许多礼物。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What did you get for Christmas?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你圣诞节收到了什么礼物？
Sense.EXAMPLE: We get a lot of junk mail.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们收到许多垃圾邮件。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We got a letter from Pam this morning.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天早上我们收到了帕姆的来信。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I got it off my Dad.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是我从我爸那里拿来的。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I got a few games free when I bought my computer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我买电脑的时候得到了几个免费的游戏。

Sense.DEF: to obtain something by finding it, asking for it, or paying for it
Sense.TRAN: 〔通过寻找﹑要求或出钱〕获得﹐得到
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need to get help quickly!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要马上得到帮助！
Sense.EXAMPLE: It would be a good idea to get professional advice.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 征求专业人士的意见﹐这个主意很好。
Sense.EXAMPLE: You may be able to get a grant from the local authority.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你也许可以从当地政府获得拨款。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He cleared his throat to get our attention.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他清清嗓子来引起我们的注意。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I want you to get some information for me.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我要你去给我找一些资料来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: His father managed to get him a job at the local factory.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他父亲想办法在当地的这家工厂里给他找了份工作。

Sense.DEF: to bring someone or something back from somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: Run upstairs and get a pillow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 赶紧去楼上拿个枕头来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I went back into the office to get a pen.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我回办公室拿了一支钢笔。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Shall I go and get the phone book?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 要我去把电话号码簿拿来吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She’s just gone to get the kids from school.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她刚去学校接孩子了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll get a towel for you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给你拿块毛巾来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll get you a chair.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给你搬把椅子来。

Subsense.DEF: to buy something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Where did you get that jacket?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你那件夹克衫是哪里买的？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Joe’s going to get tickets for all of us.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔要去给我们大家买票。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: While you’re out, could you get me some batteries?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你出去时给我买几节电池好吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s just got himself a new van.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他刚刚给自己买了一辆新的厢式货车。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I usually get vegetables from the supermarket.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一般在这家超市里买蔬菜。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You can get a decent PC for about £500 now.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 现在大约500英镑就可以买一台不错的个人电脑了。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: It’s a lovely coat, and I managed to get it cheap in the sales.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这件外套很漂亮﹐我是减价的时候买的﹐很便宜。

Subsense.DEF: to pay for something for someone else
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’ll get these drinks.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些饮料我来付钱。

Subsense.DEF: to buy a newspaper regularly
Subsense.EXAMPLE: My parents always used to get the ‘Daily Telegraph’.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我父母以前总是买《每日电讯报》。

Subsense.DEF: to receive money for doing work
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Hospital doctors get a minimum of £50,000 a year.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 医院的医生一年起码挣5万英镑。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He gets £4 an hour for stacking shelves.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他给货架上货一小时挣4英镑。

Subsense.DEF: to receive money when you sell something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You should get a couple of hundred pounds for your old car.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你的旧车应该可以卖几百英镑。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: Did you get a good price for it?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你卖到好价钱了吗？

Sense.DEF: to start to have a feeling or an idea
Sense.TRAN: 产生﹐获得〔某种感觉或想法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: She began to get an uncomfortable feeling that she was being watched.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她开始有一种不安的感觉﹐觉得有人在监视她。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got a terrible shock when I saw how ill he looked.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看到他病成这样﹐我大吃一惊。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got the impression that everyone was fed up with us.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我感觉到大家对我们厌烦了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She gets a lot of pleasure from her garden.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她从自己的花园里获得很多乐趣。

Sense.DEF: to have, do, or experience something
Sense.EXAMPLE: You don’t get enough exercise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你锻炼得不够多。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I never get time to read these days.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些日子我根本没有时间看书。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The west of the country gets quite a lot of rain.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国西部地区经常下雨。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We might get the chance to go to America this year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今年我们可能有机会去美国。

Sense.DEF: to catch an illness
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got flu last winter and was in bed for three weeks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年冬天我得了流感﹐在床上躺了三个星期。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was worried she might get food poisoning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她担心自己可能会食物中毒。

Sense.DEF: to achieve something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got 98% in my last maths test.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 上一次数学考试我得了98分。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the person who gets the highest score
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 得分最高的人

Sense.DEF: to receive something as a punishment
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got ten years in prison for his part in the robbery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因参与抢劫被判刑十年。

Sense.DEF: to arrive somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time will we get there?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们什么时候可以到那里？
Sense.EXAMPLE: We didn’t get home until midnight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们半夜才到家。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We got to Paris that evening.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那天晚上我们到了巴黎。

Sense.DEF: to reach a particular point or stage of something
Sense.TRAN: 达到〔某一点或某一阶段〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve got as far as chapter 5.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我已经看到第5章了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t wait to get to the end of the book.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我迫不及待地想把书看完。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Where have you got up to in the story?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这小说你看到哪里了？
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was disappointing to lose, having got this far in the competition.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 比赛到了这一步却输掉了﹐真是让人失望。

Sense.DEF: if you get somewhere, or if an action gets you somewhere, you make progress
Sense.TRAN: （某人）有所进展/有任何进展/没有进展
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think we’re getting somewhere at last.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我们终于有了一些进展。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We didn’t seem to be getting anywhere.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们好像没有任何进展。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve tried arguing, but it got me nowhere.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我争也争过了﹐可是没有用。

Sense.DEF: to move or go somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get out of my house!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 滚出我的房子！
Sense.EXAMPLE: We managed to get past the guards.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们设法从警卫身边溜了过去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: They shouted at us to get back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们喊着要我们回去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Peter got to his feet stood up .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 彼得站了起来。

Sense.DEF: to make something or someone move to a different place or position, especially with some difficulty
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t get the disk out of the computer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没法从电脑里取出磁盘。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Could you help me get the wardrobe up the stairs?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你能帮我把大衣柜搬到楼上去吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: We must get food and emergency aid into the area as quickly as possible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须尽快把食品和紧急救援物资送进那个地区。

Sense.DEF: to travel somewhere on a train, bus etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can get a bus to the station.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以乘巴士去火车站。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got the 9.15 from London to Edinburgh.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我乘坐的是9点15分从伦敦开往爱丁堡的火车。

Sense.DEF: to change to a new feeling, situation, or state
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t get upset.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别难过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She soon got bored with the job.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不久就厌倦了这份工作。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He calmed down as he got older.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的性子随着年龄增长变得平和了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Eat your dinner before it gets cold.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吃饭吧﹐一会儿就凉了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This is getting silly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事越来越荒唐了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s getting to be a problem.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这将是个问题。

Sense.DEF: to make someone or something change to a new feeling, situation, or state
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sometimes she gets me so angry!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有时候她会把我惹得非常生气！
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t get the children too excited.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别让孩子们太兴奋了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was terrified of getting her pregnant.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他害怕使她怀孕。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It took them 15 minutes to get the boat ready.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们花了15分钟把船备好。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something, especially something bad, happens to someone or something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You might get hurt if you stand there.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你站在那里可能会被伤到。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Mind the camera doesn’t get broken.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小心不要把相机弄坏了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My dad got killed in a car crash.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我爸爸在一次车祸中丧生。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I knew I would get shouted at if I was late home.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我知道我如果回家晚了就会挨骂。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This is a question we very often get asked.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个问题经常有人问我们。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She got her foot caught in the wire.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的脚卡在铁丝网里了。

Sense.SIGNTRAN: 使某事发生在某人身上/某物上

Subsense.DEF: to accidentally make someone or something experience something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: You’re going to get us all killed!
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你会让我们都没命的！
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Mind you don’t get yourself burned.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小心别烫到自己。

Subsense.DEF: to do something, or arrange for it to be done
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I need to get the washing machine fixed.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我需要叫人来修洗衣机。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We must get this work finished on time.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须按时把这活儿干完。

Sense.DEF: to make something do a particular thing

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t get the engine to start.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我发动不了引擎。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We got the lawn mower working again eventually.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们终于又让割草机转了起来。

Sense.DEF: to persuade or force someone to do something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll get Terry to check the wiring for me.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我会让特里帮我检查线路。

Sense.EXAMPLE: We couldn’t get him to sign the agreement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们没法让他签协议。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: In the end, we got the children clearing the playground.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 最后﹐我们让孩子们把操场清理干净了。

Sense.GRAM: T not in passive or progressive
Sense.DEF: to understand something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t think she got the joke.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想她是没有听懂这个笑话。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t get it – it doesn’t make sense.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不明白——这讲不通嘛。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I still don’t get how she knew about the meeting.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我还是不明白她是怎么知道开会的事的。

Sense.DEF: to prepare food or a meal
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s just getting lunch.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她正在准备午饭。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Shall I get you a sandwich?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给你弄个三明治好吗？

Sense.GRAM: T not in passive or progressive
Sense.DEF: to be able to receive a particular radio signal, television station etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can you get satellite TV here?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你这里可以收看卫星电视吗？

Sense.DEF: to answer the door or telephone
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can you get the phone?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你去接下电话好吗？

Sense.DEF: to catch someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police got him in the end.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警察终于抓到了他。

Sense.DEF: to attack, hurt, or kill someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The other gang members threatened to get him if he went to the police.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 其他的黑帮成员威胁说﹐他要是去报警就把他干掉。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll get you for this!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事我会找你算账的！

Sense.DEF: to deceive or trick someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: I got you that time!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那一次我是骗你的！

Sense.DEF: if you get someone on the telephone, they answer the telephone when you have made a call, and so you talk to them
Sense.EXAMPLE: I tried phoning him at work, but I just got his secretary.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我打过电话到他上班的地方﹐可接电话的却是他的秘书。

Sense.DEF: to begin doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We got talking about the old days.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们开始谈起了过去的时光。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think we should get going quite soon.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我们应该很快就要开始了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What are we all waiting for? Let’s get moving!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们都在等什么呢？开始吧！

Sense.DEF: to have the opportunity to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We got to meet all the stars after the show.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 演出之后我们得以见到了所有的明星。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She gets to travel all over the place with her job.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她做这个工作可以到各地旅行。

Sense.DEF: to gradually begin to like, know, or understand someone or something
Sense.TRAN: 渐渐喜欢/认识/理解某人/某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’ll take a while for you to get to know everyone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你需要一段时间才能认识每一个人。
Sense.EXAMPLE: After a while, I got to like him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 过了一阵子﹐我开始喜欢上他了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something happens or exists
Sense.EXAMPLE: I didn’t know you got tigers in Europe.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道你们欧洲有老虎。

Sense.DEF: used to say you do not know the answer to something
Sense.TRAN: 你把我难倒了﹐你把我问住了

Sense.DEF: used to say that something really annoys you
Sense.EXAMPLE: It really gets me the way he leaves wet towels on the bathroom floor.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我非常讨厌他把湿毛巾扔在卫生间地板上。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What gets me is their attitude.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 让我反感的是他们的态度。

Sense.DEF: used to draw attention to something surprising or interesting that you are about to mention
Sense.TRAN: 你看〔用以吸引对方对某事物的注意〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: And the whole thing only cost – get this – $12.95.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 全部只要——你看——12.95美元。

Exponent.DEF: to get something by finding it, asking for it, or paying for it
Exponent.TRAN: 〔通过寻找﹑要求或出钱〕获得﹐得到
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’ve been trying to get some information.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一直在设法得到些信息。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She went to the bank to get some money.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她去银行取些钱。

Exponent.DEF: to get something
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Maps and guides can be obtained from the tourist office.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 可以从旅游服务处获取地图和指南。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The newspaper has obtained a copy of the letter.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家报纸得到了那封信的副本。

Exponent.DEF: to get something – used about knowledge, skills, or something big or expensive
Exponent.TRAN: 得到﹐获得〔知识﹑技能﹐或大的﹑昂贵的东西〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The course helps older people to acquire computing skills.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这门课程帮助年长者掌握计算机技能。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He acquired the property in 1985.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在1985年购买了这份产业。

Exponent.DEF: to get someone’s money or property after they die
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Jo inherited a lot of money from her mother.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔从他母亲那里继承了一大笔钱。

Exponent.DEF: to get something useful or necessary, such as knowledge or experience
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’ve gained a lot of useful experience.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我获得了很多有用的经验。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The research helped us gain an insight into how a child’s mind works.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项研究帮助我们了解儿童的思维方式。

Exponent.DEF: to get something because you deserve it
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He had earned a reputation as a peacemaker.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他得到了一个和事佬的名声。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She earned a lot of respect from her colleagues.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她深受同事们尊重。

Exponent.DEF: to get something that is rare or difficult to find
Exponent.TRAN: 得到〔稀罕或很难弄到的〕某物
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I’m trying to get hold of a ticket for the game.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在设法搞一张这场比赛的入场券。

Exponent.DEF: to get something that you want very much or that you have spent a lot of time looking for
Exponent.TRAN: 弄到某物〔指非常想要或寻觅多时的东西〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I read every book I could lay my hands on.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我有书必读。

Sense.DEF: to go or travel to different places
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s 80 now, and doesn’t get about much any more.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她现在80岁﹐不再经常出门走动了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s got an old van which he uses for getting about.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有一辆旧面包车﹐出门就靠它。

Sense.DEF: if news or information gets about, it is told to a lot of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t really want this to get about.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我实在不想让这事传开。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in communicating an idea or piece of information to someone, or to be communicated successfully

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It took him ages to get his point across.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他花了好长时间才把他的意思说清楚。

Sense.EXAMPLE: We must get across the simple fact that drugs are dangerous.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须让人们知道这个简单的事实——毒品是危险的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The message isn’t getting across.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个意思没有被人们理解。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It is important that we get this message across to voters.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一定要把这个信息传递给选民。

Sense.DEF: to be successful and do better than other people in a job or work
Sense.EXAMPLE: She soon found that it wasn’t easy to get ahead in the movie business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不久﹐她就发现在电影圈里出人头地并不容易。

Sense.DEF: if two or more people get along, they have a friendly relationship
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve always got along quite well.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一向相处得很好。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They seem to get along with each other.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他俩好像相处得不错。

Sense.DEF: to deal with a job or situation or to make progress
Sense.EXAMPLE: How’s Sam getting along at university?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 萨姆在大学里过得怎么样?

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Don’t worry, we’ll get along without you.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要担心﹐没有你我们也能应付。

Sense.LEXUNIT: I must/I’d better be getting along
Sense.DEF: used to say that it is time for you to leave, for example because you have something else to do
to go or travel to different places
Sense.EXAMPLE: We had to use public transport to get around.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们只得使用公共交通工具出行。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s quite easy to get around London.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伦敦出行很方便。

Sense.DEF: if news or information gets around, it is told to a lot of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: News of the accident soon got around.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 发生事故的消息很快就传开了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Word got around that the department might be closed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有消息说这个部门可能要关闭。

Sense.DEF: to avoid something that is difficult or causes problems for you
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think we should be able to get around most of these problems.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想这些问题大部分我们都能解决。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was always very clever at getting around the rules.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她总是很善于避开规章制度。

Sense.DEF: to do something that you have been intending to do for some time
Sense.TRAN: 终于去做〔一直想做的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I meant to phone her yesterday, but I never got around to it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我本打算昨天给她打电话的﹐可一直没有时间。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We finally got around to clearing out the garage.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们终于把车库清理了。

Sense.DEF: to keep criticizing someone in an unkind way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why is he always getting at me?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他为什么老是责备我？
Sense.EXAMPLE: He felt he was being got at by the other students.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他觉得自己老是受到其他同学刁难。

Sense.DEF: to be trying to say something in a way that is difficult for other people to understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: What are you getting at, Helen?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你到底想说什么﹐海伦？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you see the point I’m getting at?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你明白我的意思吗？

Sense.DEF: to be able to reach something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We had to move the washing machine out to get at the wiring behind it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们只得把洗衣机挪出来﹐才能够到后面的电源线。

Sense.DEF: to discover information, especially the truth about a situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was determined to get at the truth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我决心要查明事情的真相。

Sense.DEF: to use threats to influence the decision of people who are involved in a court case
Sense.TRAN: 恐吓〔涉及案件审理的人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you think some of the jury have been got at?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你认为陪审团里有人受到恐吓了吗？

Sense.DEF: to leave a place, especially when this is not easy
Sense.EXAMPLE: The meeting dragged on, and I didn’t get away until seven.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 会议开个没完﹐我直到七点钟才脱身。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I like to get away from London at the weekend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我喜欢离开伦敦出去过周末。

Sense.DEF: to take a holiday away from the place you normally live
Sense.EXAMPLE: Will you manage to get away this summer?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今年夏天你能外出度假吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re hoping to get away to Scotland for a few days.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望到苏格兰度几天假。

Sense.DEF: to escape from someone who is chasing you or trying to catch you
Sense.EXAMPLE: The three men got away in a stolen car.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那三个人开着一辆偷来的汽车逃掉了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We knew it wouldn’t be easy to get away from the police.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们知道要摆脱警察不容易。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The thieves got away with jewellery worth over £50,000.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 窃贼带着价值5万多英镑的珠宝逃之夭夭。

Sense.DEF: used to say you are very surprised by something or do not believe it
Sense.TRAN: 别胡扯！〔表示惊讶或不相信〕

Sense.DEF: something good that you nearly had or that nearly happened
Sense.TRAN: 几乎到手的好东西﹐差点发生的好事

Sense.DEF: to avoid something that is difficult or unpleasant for you, or something that limits what you can do in some way
Sense.TRAN: 摆脱〔困难或不愉快的事﹐或某种限制〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I needed to get away from the pressures of work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我需要排遣工作的压力。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She wanted to get away from the traditional ideas of what thea-tre is about.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她想摆脱传统的戏剧观念。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There is no getting away from this fact you cannot avoid or deny this fact.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是无法回避的事实。

Sense.DEF: to begin to talk about other things rather than the subject you are supposed to be discussing
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think we’re getting away from the main issue.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我们偏离了主题。

Sense.DEF: to have a relaxing holiday
Sense.EXAMPLE: You need to get away from it all for a couple of weeks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你需要放下一切﹐休息几个星期。

Sense.DEF: to not be caught or punished when you have done something wrong
Sense.TRAN: 〔做错事而〕不被发现﹐不受惩罚
Sense.EXAMPLE: Watch Frank – he’ll cheat if he thinks he can get away with it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 留神弗兰克——他逮到机会就会作弊。
Sense.EXAMPLE: No one insults my family and gets away with it!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有人可以白白地侮辱我的家人！

Sense.DEF: to not be punished for doing something wrong
Sense.EXAMPLE: Some of those children get away with murder!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那些孩子有的简直无法无天！

Sense.DEF: to receive only a small punishment for something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The charge was reduced to manslaughter, and she got away with three years in prison.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 罪名减轻为过失杀人﹐她只被判刑三年。

Sense.DEF: to do something without experiencing any problems or difficulties, even though it is not the best thing to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: At school he had always got away with doing the bare minimum amount of work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他上学的时候功课总是能不做就不做。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The colour’s not quite right, but I think you’ll get away with it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这颜色不是很合适﹐不过我想你穿问题不大。

Sense.DEF: to return to a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll talk to you when I get back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我回来再和你谈。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He got back to the office just before lunchtime.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他回到办公室的时候正好快要吃午饭了。

Sense.DEF: to start doing something again or talking about something again

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Let’s get back to the main point of the discussion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们还是回到讨论的要点吧。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Well, I must get back to work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好啦﹐我得回去干活了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Have you ever thought about getting back into teaching?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你有没有想过再去教书？

Sense.DEF: to change to a previous state or condition again

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Life was beginning to get back to normal.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 生活开始恢复正常了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t get back to sleep.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我再也睡不着了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Do you think they’ll get back together start having a relationship again ?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你说他们还能和好如初吗？

Sense.DEF: to get something again after you have lost it or someone else has taken it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Did you get your books back?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你的书拿回来了吗？

Sense.DEF: to do something to hurt or harm someone who has hurt or harmed you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll get you back for this!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事我会找你算账的！

Sense.DEF: to do something to hurt or harm someone who has hurt or harmed you
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’ll probably go out with her just to get back at me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他约她出去﹐可能就是为了报复我。

Sense.DEF: to talk to someone or telephone them later in order to answer a question or give them information
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll find out the prices and get back to you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我查一下价格再给你答复。

Sense.DEF: if you get behind with a job, payments, rent etc, you do not do or pay as much of it as you should have by a particular time
Sense.TRAN: 〔工作﹑付款﹑房租等〕拖后﹔拖欠﹐拖延

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I don’t want to get behind with my work.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不想拖延工作。

Sense.EXAMPLE: You can always catch up later if you get behind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你落后了﹐以后总是可以赶上。

Sense.DEF: to support someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The crowd really got behind them and cheered them on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 观众很支持他们﹐给他们鼓劲加油。

Sense.DEF: to have enough money to buy the things you need, but no more
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t earn a huge salary, but we get by.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我薪水不高﹐但我们还能凑合。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Sometimes they had to get by on very little.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有时候他们只得靠一点点钱勉强过日子。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel unhappy and tired
Sense.TRAN: 使某人忧郁﹐使某人沮丧
Sense.EXAMPLE: His lack of social life was beginning to get him down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他缺少社交生活﹐慢慢地就变得很消沉了。

Sense.DEF: to write something, especially something that someone is saying
Sense.TRAN: 写下﹐记下〔尤指某人说的话〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was followed by a group of reporters trying to get down every word he said.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他后面跟着一群记者﹐想把他说的每个字都记下来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s important to get things down on paper.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一定要把事情记在纸上。

Sense.DEF: to eat or drink something, or persuade someone else to eat or drink something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I knew I’d feel better once I’d got some food down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我知道只要吃点东西我就会好起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get that tea down you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你把那杯茶喝了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He still says he’s not hungry, and I can’t get anything down him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他还是说不饿﹐我没法让他吃任何东西。

Sense.DEF: to leave the table after a meal – used by children or when you are talking to children
Sense.EXAMPLE: Please may I get down?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我可以下桌了吗？

Sense.DEF: to start doing something that is difficult or needs a lot of time or energy
Sense.TRAN: 开始做〔需要花费许多时间或精力的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s time we got down to work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们该开始干活了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need to get down to some serious talking.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要认真谈一谈。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I always find it hard to get down to revising.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一直觉得很难打起精神开始温习。

Sense.DEF: to enter a place, especially when this is difficult
Sense.TRAN: 进入〔某地﹐尤指难进的地方〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We managed to get in through a window.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们设法从一扇窗户爬了进去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The theatre was already full, and we couldn’t get in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 剧院已经满座了﹐我们进不去。

Sense.DEF: if a train, plane etc gets in at a particular time, it arrives at that time
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time does the bus get in?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公共汽车什么时候到？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We get in to Heathrow at ten o’clock.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们十点钟抵达希思罗机场。

Sense.DEF: to arrive home
Sense.EXAMPLE: We didn’t get in until late.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们很晚才到家。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time do the boys get in from school?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 男孩子们什么时候放学回家？

Sense.DEF: to be elected to a position of political power
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Conservatives have promised to increase spending on health and education if they get in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保守党承诺当选后增加卫生和教育开支。

Sense.DEF: to be allowed to be a student at a university, college etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: I applied to Bristol University, but I didn’t get in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我申请了布里斯托尔大学﹐但是没被录取。

Sense.DEF: to buy a supply of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I must remember to get some food in for the weekend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一定要记得买点食品周末的时候吃。

Sense.DEF: to gather a crop and bring it to a sheltered place
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole village was involved with getting the harvest in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 全村的人都在收割庄稼。

Sense.DEF: to ask someone to come to your home to do a job, especially to repair something
Sense.TRAN: 请某人来家里做事〔尤指修理〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll have to get a plumber in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们得请一个管子工来。

Sense.DEF: to send something to a paticular place or give it to a particular person
Sense.EXAMPLE: Please can you get your essays in by Thursday.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请你们在星期四以前把文章交上来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s best to get your insurance claim in as quickly as possible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保险索赔最好尽快递交。

Sense.DEF: to manage to do something even though you do not have much time
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re hoping to get in a game of golf over the weekend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望周末能打一场高尔夫球。

Sense.DEF: to become involved in something that other people are doing or planning
Sense.TRAN: 参与〔别人正在做或计划的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Quite a few companies would like to get in on the project.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不少公司都想参与这个项目。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The scheme has proved very successful, and now other local authorities are keen to get in on the act become involved in something exciting or interesting .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个计划非常成功﹐现在其他地方当局也跃跃欲试。

Sense.DEF: to become friendly with someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got in with a bad crowd and started getting into trouble.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他结交了一帮坏人﹐开始惹是生非了。

Sense.DEF: to enter a place, especially when this is difficult
Sense.EXAMPLE: The door was locked and we couldn’t get into the house.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 门锁着﹐我们没法进屋。

Sense.DEF: to arrive at a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time do we get into New York?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们什么时候到纽约？

Sense.DEF: to be elected to a Parliament
Sense.EXAMPLE: He first got into Parliament in 1982.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 1982年﹐他第一次入选议会。

Sense.DEF: to be allowed to be a student at a university, college etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: She got into UCLA.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她进了加州大学洛杉矶分校。

Sense.DEF: to be made a member of a team
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you think you might get into the Olympic team this year?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你觉得你能进入今年的奥运队吗？

Sense.DEF: to start doing or feeling something, or being in a particular situation
Sense.TRAN: 养成〔某种习惯〕﹔陷入〔某种情绪〕﹔处于〔某种情形〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s started getting into trouble at school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他开始在学校里惹出麻烦了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My parents were always terrified of getting into debt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我父母一直害怕背上债务。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She got into the habit of going for long walks by herself.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她养成了一个人长时间散步的习惯。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got into a terrible temper and started throwing things around.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他大发脾气﹐开始乱扔东西。

Sense.DEF: to begin to be involved in doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: How did you first get into script writing?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你是如何开始从事编剧工作的？
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was starting to get into politics.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她正开始涉足政坛。

Sense.DEF: to begin to enjoy something or be interested in it
Sense.EXAMPLE: I first got into jazz when I was at college.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我上大学时开始对爵士乐产生了兴趣。

Sense.DEF: to put on a piece of clothing, especially when this is difficult because the piece of clothing is too small for you
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know how she managed to get into those trousers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道那条裤子她是怎么穿进去的。

Sense.DEF: used to express surprise that someone is behaving very differently from the way they usually behave
Sense.TRAN: 某人是怎么了？〔用于对某人的异常表现表示惊讶〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know what’s got into Sally recently.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道萨莉最近是怎么了。

Sense.DEF: to leave a place, or to help someone to leave a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll try and get off straight after lunch.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们尽量吃过午饭就出发。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Get off my land!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 从我的地盘走开！

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll phone you as soon as I’ve got the children off to school.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把孩子们打发上学后马上打电话给你。

Sense.DEF: to finish work and leave the place where you work at the end of the day
Sense.EXAMPLE: I usually get off at six o’clock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一般六点钟下班。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time do you get off work ?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你什么时候下班？

Sense.DEF: to send a letter or package by post
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll have to get this letter off by tonight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我得在今晚前把这封信寄出去。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ll get the forms off to you today.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天我会把表格寄给你。

Sense.DEF: to remove a piece of clothing
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why don’t you get those wet clothes off?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你干吗不把湿衣服脱下来？

Sense.DEF: if someone gets off, they are not punished for doing something wrong, or they receive only a small punishment
Sense.TRAN: 没有受到惩罚﹔被从轻处罚
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the end he got off because there wasn’t enough evidence against him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 最后因为证据不足﹐他没有受到惩罚。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The police felt he had got off very lightly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方认为对他的处罚太轻了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you’re lucky, you’ll get off with a fine.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你运气好的话﹐罚点钱就可以了。

Sense.DEF: to help someone avoid being punished for a crime
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her lawyers were confident that they could get her off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的律师有信心让她免受惩罚。

Sense.DEF: to go to sleep, or to help a child go to sleep
Sense.EXAMPLE: I went to bed but couldn’t get off to sleep .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我上了床﹐但是睡不着。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It took us ages to get the baby off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们好久才把宝宝哄睡着。

Sense.LEXUNIT: get off to a good/bad etc start
Sense.DEF: to start in a particular way
Sense.EXAMPLE: The day had got off to a bad start.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一天一开始就不顺利。

Sense.DEF: to stop talking about a subject
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can we get off the subject of death, please?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们不说死亡这个话题了好不好？

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone to stop touching something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get off me!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别碰我！
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get off those cakes, or there’ll be trouble.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别碰那些蛋糕﹐否则有你好看的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get off stop touching me !
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别碰我！

Sense.LEXUNIT: tell sb where to get off
Sense.DEF: to tell someone that they are asking you for too much or are behaving in a way you will not accept
Sense.EXAMPLE: He wanted £50, but I told him where to get off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他想要50英镑﹐我叫他别太过分。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone that they should stop being lazy and start doing something useful
Sense.TRAN: 抬起屁股收收你的懒骨头

Sense.DEF: to become excited by something, especially sexually excited
Sense.TRAN: 因…感到兴奋〔尤指性兴奋〕

Sense.DEF: to start a sexual relationship with someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: She spent the whole evening trying to get off with Phil.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她一晚上都在勾引菲尔。

Sense.DEF: if people get on, they like each other and have a friendly relationship with each other

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ve always got on well with Henry.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我和亨利一向相处得很好。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The two boys get on well most of the time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这两个男孩大部分时间都相处得很好。

Sense.DEF: to deal with a job or situation or to make progress
Sense.EXAMPLE: How is George getting on at school?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔治在学校里怎么样？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: How are you getting on with your essay?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你文章写得怎么样了？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I don’t know how we’ll get on without Michael.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道没有迈克尔我们该怎么办。

Sense.DEF: to continue doing something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Be quiet and get on with your work!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 安静﹐继续干你的事！

Sense.DEF: to be successful in your job
Sense.EXAMPLE: You’ll have to work hard if you want to get on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你想取得成功﹐就得努力工作。

Sense.DEF: to put a piece of clothing on
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t get my boots on!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的靴子穿不上！

Subsense.DEF: if time is getting on, it is quite late
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Come on, it’s getting on and we ought to go home.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 快点﹐天晚了﹐我们该回家了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I realized that time was getting on and we would have to hurry.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我意识到时间不早了﹐我们得赶快了。

Subsense.DEF: if someone is getting on, they are quite old

Sense.DEF: almost a particular age, time, number etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mrs McIntyre must be getting on for 90 by now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 麦金太尔夫人现在肯定都快90岁了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The total cost was getting on for $100,000.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 全部费用将近10万美元。

Sense.DEF: to have sex
used to tell someone to hurry
Sense.EXAMPLE: Will you lot stop messing around and get on with it!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们别磨蹭了﹐快一点啦！

Sense.LEXUNIT: let sb get on with it
Sense.DEF: to let someone do something on their own, and not help them or tell them what to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: She wanted to decorate her room, so I just let her get on with it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她想把自己的房间装修一下﹐所以我就让她自己去搞。

Sense.SIGNTRAN: 和某人说话/写信给某人
Sense.DEF: to speak or write to someone
Sense.TRAN: 和〔某人〕说话﹔写信给〔某人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll get onto my lawyer about this.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事我要问我的律师。

Sense.DEF: to find out about someone who has been doing something wrong
Sense.TRAN: 发觉﹐识破〔某人进行不良勾当〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: How did the police get onto him?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方是怎么发现他的？

Sense.DEF: to be elected as a member of a committee, a political organization etc
Sense.TRAN: 当选〔委员会﹑政治组织等〕的成员
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was quite keen to get onto the management committee.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她很想进入管理委员会。

Sense.DEF: to begin to talk about a subject after you have been discussing something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: After a few minutes they got onto the subject of the election.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 几分钟后他们谈起了选举这个话题。

Sense.DEF: to start dealing with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Right, I’ll get onto it straight away.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好吧﹐我马上着手处理此事。

Sense.DEF: to leave a room or building
Sense.EXAMPLE: You ought to get out into the fresh air.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你应该出去透透气。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mary screamed at me to get out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽尖叫着要我出去。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Get out of the kitchen!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 出去﹐别待在厨房里！

Sense.DEF: to escape from a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Some of the animals had got out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些动物逃出去了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was determined to get out of prison.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他决心要从监狱里逃出去。

Sense.DEF: to help someone leave a place or escape from a place
Sense.TRAN: 把某人弄出去﹔使某人逃出来
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s important to get these people out as soon as possible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尽快救出这些人是很重要的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We knew it was going to be difficult to get him out of the country.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们知道要帮他从这个国家逃出来是很困难的。

Sense.DEF: to take something from the place where it is kept
Sense.EXAMPLE: She got out her violin and started to play.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她拿出小提琴拉了起来。

Sense.DEF: if information gets out, a lot of people then know it although it is meant to be secret
Sense.EXAMPLE: We have to make absolutely certain that none of this gets out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们得绝对保证这事一点也不被泄露出去。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s bound to get out that he’s retiring soon.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他要退休的消息肯定会传出去的。

Sense.DEF: to produce a book or other product that can be sold to people
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re hoping to get the new catalogue out next week.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们希望下个星期能把新的商品目录印出来。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in saying something, especially when this is very difficult
Sense.EXAMPLE: I wanted to tell him I loved him, but couldn’t get the words out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想告诉他我爱他﹐但是说不出口。

Sense.DEF: to avoid doing something you have promised to do or are supposed to do
Sense.EXAMPLE: See if you can get out of that meeting tomorrow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看看明天的会议你能不能逃过。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s trying to get out of tidying his room.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他想逃避收拾房间。

Sense.DEF: to stop doing something or being involved in something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I wanted to get out of teaching.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想放弃教书的工作。

Sense.SIGNTRAN: 让某人给予某物/告诉某事
Sense.DEF: to force or persuade someone to tell you something or give you something
Sense.TRAN: 要某人说出某事﹔要某人给予某物
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was determined to get the truth out of her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一定要让她说出真相。

Sense.DEF: to enjoy something you do or experience, or to learn something as a result
Sense.TRAN: 从某事中得到[学到]某事
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hope he got something out of his visit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我希望他通过这次访问可以有所获益。

GramExa.PROPFORM: get sth out of doing sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Children can get a lot out of being involved in community projects.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿童参加社区活动可以学到不少东西。

Sense.DEF: to become well again after an illness
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s taken me ages to get over the flu.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我得了流感﹐很久才好起来。

Sense.DEF: to begin to feel better after a very upsetting experience
Sense.TRAN: 从〔不愉快的经历〕中恢复
Sense.EXAMPLE: She never got over the death of her son.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于儿子的死﹐她一直没有想开。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in communicating ideas or information to other people

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s important that we get this message over to young people.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一定要让年轻人明白这个道理。

Sense.DEF: to do and finish something difficult that you have to do
Sense.TRAN: 完成某事〔指必须做的难事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll be in touch once I’ve got my exams over.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我考完试后马上和你联系。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t wait to get the interview over with.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我巴不得面试早点结束。

Sense.DEF: to successfully deal with a problem or difficulty
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know how we’re going to get over this problem.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道我们该怎样解决这个问题。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Once we’ve got over the first few months, we should be making a reasonable profit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只要把头几个月应付过去﹐我们就应该能获得不错的利润。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you are very surprised, shocked, or amused by something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t get over how well you look.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很惊讶你的气色这么好。

Sense.DEF: if news or information gets round, it is told to a lot of people
Sense.EXAMPLE: News like this soon gets round.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这样的消息传得很快。

Sense.DEF: to avoid something that is difficult or causes problems for you
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most companies manage to get round the restrictions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数公司都设法避开这些限制。

Sense.DEF: to gently persuade someone to do what you want by being nice to them
Sense.EXAMPLE: I know how to get round Chris.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我知道怎么哄克里斯。

Sense.DEF: to do something that you have been intending to do for some time
Sense.EXAMPLE: I keep meaning to put a lock on it, but I never get round to it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一直想加个锁﹐但总是拖着没做。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I haven’t got round to unpacking from my holiday yet.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我度假回来连行李都还没有打开。

Sense.DEF: to do an amount of work
Sense.EXAMPLE: We got through half the application forms this morning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天早上我们看了一半的申请表。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ve got a lot of work to get through.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们有许多活儿要干。

Sense.DEF: to use a lot of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: You wouldn’t believe the amount of food children can get through in a week!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不会相信小孩子一个星期要吃多少东西！

Sense.DEF: to spend a lot of money
Sense.EXAMPLE: He can get through £100 in one evening.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一晚上就能花掉100英镑。

Sense.DEF: to come successfully to the end of an unpleasant experience or period of time, or to help someone do this
Sense.TRAN: （帮助某人）渡过〔难关〕﹐（使某人）熬过〔困难时期〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know how we’re going to get through the winter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道我们如何挨过这个冬天。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was their love that got me through those first difficult months.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 是他们的爱帮助我熬过头几个月的困难时期。

Sense.DEF: to be successful in a test or competition, or to make sure that someone or something is successful
Sense.TRAN: （使某人/某物）通过〔考试﹑检测〕﹔（使）〔在竞赛中〕胜利
Sense.EXAMPLE: I finally managed to get through my driving test.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我终于通过了驾驶考试。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I knew it was going to be difficult to get the car through its MOT test.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我知道这辆汽车很难通过车检。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Liverpool have got through to the final of the FA Cup.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利物浦队进入了足总杯决赛。

Sense.DEF: to reach a place or person that is difficult to reach
Sense.TRAN: 到达〔难以到达的地方或某人处〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Aid agencies have been unable to get through to the thousands of refugees stranded on the border.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 援助机构无法到达困在边境的数千难民那里。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in speaking to someone on the telephone
Sense.EXAMPLE: I tried phoning her office, but I couldn’t get through.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给她办公室打过电话﹐但是没联系到她。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: At last I managed to get through to one of the managers.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我终于和其中一名经理通上了电话。

Sense.DEF: if a new law gets through parliament, or if someone gets it through, it is officially approved
Sense.TRAN: （使）〔新的法律在立法机关中〕通过
Sense.EXAMPLE: Anti-hunting legislation will never get through the House of Lords.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 反狩猎的法律是不可能在上议院通过的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Once again we failed to get the Bill through Parliament.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们又一次没能让议会通过这项议案。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in making someone understand something, especially when this is difficult
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t seem to get through to her.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我好像没有办法让她明白。
Sense.EXAMPLE: How can I get it through to him that this is really important?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我怎样才能使他明白这事的确很重要呢？

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel annoyed or upset
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m under a lot of pressure at work, and sometimes it gets to me a bit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我工作压力很大﹐有时候会有点烦。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t let things get to you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不要让什么事情影响你的情绪。

Sense.DEF: to start thinking something
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got to thinking how disappointed his parents would be.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他想到自己的父母将会多么失望。

Sense.DEF: if people get together, they meet in order to spend time with each other
Sense.EXAMPLE: We must get together for a drink.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一定要聚在一起喝一杯。

Sense.DEF: if two people get together, they start a romantic or sexual relationship
Sense.TRAN: 在一起〔指两个人开始谈情说爱或发生性关系〕

Sense.DEF: to collect things together
Sense.EXAMPLE: I need to get some paperwork together for the meeting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我需要收集一些开会用的资料。

Sense.DEF: to bring people together to make a group
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got together a group of local businessmen to discuss the problem.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他召集了一群当地的企业家来讨论这个问题。

Sense.DEF: to succeed in getting enough money to do or buy something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re trying to get together enough money to buy a flat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们正在想办法筹集足够的钱买一套公寓房。

Sense.DEF: to change your life so that it is organized and you are in control of it
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s just trying to get his life together at the moment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 目前他正在设法调整自己的生活。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m staying with my parents for a while, until I’ve got myself together a bit.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我暂时和父母住在一起﹐等我调整好自己的状况再说。

Sense.DEF: to be organized and successful in your life, job etc
Sense.TRAN: 理出头绪并成功地应付〔生活﹑工作等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The government can’t seem to get it together on the environment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府好像对环境问题茫然无措。

Sense.DEF: to get out of your bed after sleeping, or to make someone get out of their bed
Sense.EXAMPLE: We didn’t get up until lunchtime.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们到吃午饭的时候才起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Get me up at seven, would you?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 七点钟叫醒我好吗？

Sense.DEF: to stand up
Sense.EXAMPLE: He got up and walked over to the window.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他站起来走到窗边。

Sense.DEF: if a wind or storm gets up, it starts and gets stronger
to be dressed in particular clothes
Sense.EXAMPLE: He arrived at the party got up as Count Dracula.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他穿成德拉库拉伯爵的样子来参加派对。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The men were all got up in suits.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 男人们个个都西装革履。

Sense.DEF:
to get an
erection 1
to do something, especially something slightly bad
Sense.EXAMPLE: Go upstairs and see what the kids are getting up to.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 上楼去看看孩子们在捣什么鬼。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What did you get up to at the weekend?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 周末你都干了些什么？

Sense.DEF: an escape from a place or unpleasant situation, especially after committing a crime
Sense.EXAMPLE: The gunmen made a getaway on foot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 持枪歹徒徒步逃跑了。

GramExa.GLOSS: a car etc used by criminals to escape after a crime
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 作案后逃跑用的汽车/车辆/面包车

Sense.DEF: a short holiday away from home, or a place where people go for a short holiday
Sense.EXAMPLE: Big Bear Lake is a popular weekend getaway .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大贝尔湖是周末度假的好去处。

Sense.DEF: from the beginning
Sense.EXAMPLE: From the get-go, I knew these tapes were special.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一开始我就知道这些磁带不一般。

Sense.DEF: a friendly informal meeting or party
Sense.EXAMPLE: a family get-together
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 家庭聚会

Sense.DEF: a set of clothes, especially strange or unusual clothes
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指奇特或不寻常的〕服装﹐装束﹐穿戴
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hardly recognized him in that getup!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那副装束﹐我几乎认不出来了！

Sense.DEF: energy and determination to do things
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was the only candidate who had any get-up-and-go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是唯一一个有干劲的候选人。

Sense.DEF: a natural spring that sends hot water and steam suddenly into the air from a hole in the ground

a machine fixed to a wall over a bath or
sink
and used for heating water
very bad or unpleasant
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ghastly little hotel
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一家很蹩脚的小旅馆
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole thing was a ghastly mistake.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 整件事情是个很糟糕的错误。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The weather was ghastly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 天气糟透了。

Sense.DEF: making you very frightened, upset, or shocked
Sense.TRAN: 可怕的﹔使人烦恼的﹔令人震惊的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a ghastly accident
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 可怕的事故

Sense.DEF: to look or feel ill, upset, or unhappy
