Sense.EXAMPLE: Sophie felt a glow of pride.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 索菲深感自豪。

Sense.DEF:
to produce or
reflect
a soft steady light
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bedside lamp glowed dimly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 床头灯发出暗淡的光。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The fireplace was still glowing with the remains of last night’s fire.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 壁炉中﹐隔夜的余烬依然在微微发光。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The red tip of his cigarette was glowing in the dark.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那红红的烟头在黑暗中幽幽发光。

Sense.DEF: if your face or body glows, it is pink or hot because you are healthy, have been doing exercise, or are feeling a strong emotion

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She looked exceptionally well, glowing with health .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她气色特别好﹐满面红光。

Sense.DEF: to look very happy because you feel proud etc
Sense.TRAN: 由于自豪/愉快/高兴等而容光焕发
Sense.EXAMPLE: She gazed up at him, glowing with happiness.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她抬头凝望着他﹐脸上洋溢着幸福。

Sense.DEF: if something glows with a quality or colour, it is attractive and has strong colours
Sense.TRAN: 发出艳丽色彩﹔散发某种品质

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The interior of the house glowed with colour, warmth, and life.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 屋子里色彩明亮﹐充满了温馨和生活气息。

Sense.DEF: to look at someone in an angry way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She glowered at him disapprovingly.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不悦地瞪着他。

Sense.DEF: a report etc that is full of praise
Sense.TRAN: 热情赞扬的报告/叙述/描写等
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve had glowing reports from Neil about your work.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼尔在我面前盛赞你的工作。

Sense.DEF: using a lot of praise
Sense.TRAN: 以赞扬的词句﹐赞不绝口地
Sense.EXAMPLE: He speaks of you in glowing terms.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他说到你就赞不绝口。

Sense.DEF: a small plastic stick with chemicals inside that produce a coloured light when they are mixed together
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dancers were waving glowsticks.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 跳舞的人挥动着荧光棒。

Sense.DEF: an insect that produces a small amount of light from its body
a natural form of sugar that exists in fruit
a sticky substance used for joining things together
to join two things together using glue

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The sheets are glued together with strong adhesive.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 薄板用强力胶粘在一起。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Check that you have glued everything in place properly.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 检查是否每一样东西都粘牢了。

Subsense.DEF: to look at something with all your attention
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He was glued to the TV when the Olympics were on.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 电视上一有奥运会比赛﹐他就会目不转睛地盯着看。

Subsense.DEF: to not move because you are very interested, surprised, frightened etc
Subsense.TRAN: 〔由于感兴趣﹑惊讶﹑害怕等而〕像钉在某物上似的一动不动
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We were glued to our chairs, listening intently to every word.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们像钉在椅子上似的﹐专心地听着每一句话。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Sarah was glued to the spot, terrified by the scene in front of her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 萨拉像钉在地上似的﹐被眼前的景象吓坏了。

Sense.DEF: the habit of breathing in gases from glues in order to produce a state of pleasure
sticky like glue
covered with glue
if someone is glum, they feel unhappy and do not talk a lot
Sense.EXAMPLE: Anna looked glum .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 安娜看上去闷闷不乐。
Sense.EXAMPLE: After dinner, Kate lapsed into a glum silence .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吃过晚饭后﹐凯特就闷声不响的。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: She stared glumly at her plate.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 她闷闷不乐地看着自己的盘子。

Sense.DEF: a supply of something, especially a product or crop, that is more than is needed

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a glut of oil on the world market
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 国际市场石油供过于求

Sense.DEF: to cause something to have too much of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: the glutted property market
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 已经饱和的房地产市场

Sense.DEF:
a sticky
protein
substance that is found in wheat flour
very sticky
Sense.EXAMPLE: glutinous mud
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 黏性泥

Sense.DEF: someone who eats too much
someone who seems to enjoy working hard or doing something unpleasant
Sense.TRAN: 不辞劳苦[任劳任怨]的人

Sense.DEF: the bad habit of eating and drinking too much
a thick sweet transparent liquid made from fats and used in medicines, explosives, and foods

a 16th-century
country house
in East Sussex in the south of England, known for the Glyndebourne Festival that takes place there every year, when
operas
are performed in its opera house. It is attended especially by rich people from the highest social class.
Sense.TRAN: 格林德伯恩庄园〔英格兰南部东萨塞克斯的一幢16世纪乡间别墅﹐以一年一度的格林德伯恩音乐节闻名〕
the written abbreviation of 书面缩写= gram or 或 grams 克

Sense.DEF:
GM foods or plants have had their
genetic
structure changed so that they are not affected by particular diseases or harmful insects
Sense.TRAN: 〔食物或植物〕转基因的﹐基因改造的

Sense.DEF:
a plant or other living thing whose
genes
have been changed by scientists, especially in order to make it less likely to get diseases or be harmed by insects etc
Sense.TRAN: 转基因生物﹐基因改造生物

Sense.DEF: a piece of equipment, like a small computer, that has special software which is able to produce an image of the natural features that exist in a particular area, such as the rocks and the water flowing under the rocks
the time as measured at Greenwich in London, that is used as an international standard for measuring time
a gnarled tree or branch is rough and twisted with hard lumps
Sense.TRAN: 〔树或树枝〕粗糙多节的﹐长满树瘤的

Sense.DEF: gnarled hands or fingers are twisted, rough, and difficult to move, usually because they are old
Sense.TRAN: 〔手或手指〕粗糙的﹐长满老茧的﹐关节扭曲的

Sense.DEF: a gnarly tree or branch is rough and twisted with hard lumps
Sense.TRAN: 〔树或树枝〕粗糙多节的﹐长满树瘤的

Sense.DEF: gnarly hands or fingers are twisted, rough, and difficult to move, usually because they are old
Sense.TRAN: 〔手或手指〕粗糙的﹐长满老茧的﹐关节扭曲的

Sense.DEF: a word meaning very good or excellent, used by young people
Sense.TRAN: 很好的﹐顶呱呱的〔年轻人用语〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Look at the size of that wave.’ ‘Gnarly!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你看这浪头多大。”“太棒了！”

Sense.DEF: a word meaning very bad, used by young people
Sense.EXAMPLE: a gnarly car wreck
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一起可怕的撞车事故

Sense.DEF: to be very angry or unhappy about something, or to move your teeth against each other so that they make a noise, especially because you are unhappy or angry
teeth
a small flying insect that bites
to keep biting something hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dexter gnawed his pen thoughtfully.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 德克斯特若有所思地咬着钢笔。
Sense.EXAMPLE: A rat had gnawed a hole in the box.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老鼠在箱子上咬了一个洞。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The puppy was gnawing on a bone.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 小狗在啃着一根骨头。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel worried or frightened, over a period of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Something was gnawing at the back of his mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些事情使他心神不安。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Doubt was gnawing away at her confidence.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 怀疑渐渐吞噬了她的信心。

Sense.DEF: worrying or painful, especially for a long time
Sense.TRAN: 折磨人的﹐令人痛苦的﹐揪心的
Sense.EXAMPLE: gnawing doubts
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 折磨人的疑虑

Sense.DEF: a creature in children’s stories who looks like a little old man. Gnomes have pointed hats, live under the ground, and guard gold, jewels etc.
Sense.TRAN: 〔儿童故事里在地下守护金子﹑珠宝等的〕土地神

Sense.DEF: a stone or plastic figure representing one of these creatures
Sense.EXAMPLE: a garden gnome
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 花园土地神石像

Sense.DEF: gnomic remarks are short, clever, and difficult to understand
the total value of all the goods and services produced in a country, usually in a single year
a large African animal with a tail and curved horns

a course of study and examination in practical subjects such as business, information technology,
engineering
etc, done by some students in schools in England and Wales, usually at the age of 16
Sense.TRAN: 全国普通职业资格证书〔英格兰和威尔士的学生通常在16岁时参加的课程〕

Subsense.DEF: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
Subsense.EXAMPLE: There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这里没有我们的事了﹐咱们回家吧。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Have you ever been to have you ever travelled to Japan?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你去过日本吗？
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I have been to have travelled to Germany several times.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我去过德国几次。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Where are you going?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你要去哪儿？
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We’re going to Canada in the summer.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们夏天要去加拿大。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Dinah went into the kitchen.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 黛娜走进厨房。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: She went over and put her arm around him.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她走过去伸手搂住他。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我准备到她家去看看出什么事了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’ll just go up go upstairs and ask him what he wants.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我这就上楼去问问他要什么。

Subsense.DEF: to move or travel in a particular way or for a particular distance
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It took us over an hour to go ten miles.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 十英里路我们用了一个多小时。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The car was going much too fast.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这车开得太快了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We went a different way from usual that day.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那天我们走的是和平常不同的路。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’ll be quicker to go by train.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 乘火车会快一些。

Subsense.GRAM: not in past tenses 不用过去式
Subsense.DEF: to move to a particular place in order to do something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Go wash your hands.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 洗手去。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I went and spoke to the manager.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我去找经理谈过了。

Sense.DEF: to move in a particular way, or to do something as you are moving
Sense.TRAN: 飞过/边走边笑/奔过去等
Sense.EXAMPLE: The plate went crashing to the floor.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 盘子哗啦一声掉在地板上。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bullet went flying over my head.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 子弹从我头顶飞过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: John went rushing off down the corridor.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰沿走廊飞奔而去。

Subsense.DEF: to be at a concert, party, meeting etc
Subsense.TRAN: 参加〔音乐会﹑聚会﹑会议等〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Are you going to Manuela’s party?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你去参加曼纽拉的派对吗？
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I first went to a rock concert when I was 15.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我15岁时第一次去听了摇滚音乐会。

Subsense.DEF: to regularly attend school, a church etc
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He doesn’t go to the synagogue these days.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他最近不去犹太教堂做礼拜了。

Sense.DEF: to leave a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: What time does the last train go?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 最后一班火车什么时候开？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Right, let’s go!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好了﹐我们走吧！
Sense.EXAMPLE: She turned to go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她转身走了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It’s late! I must get going.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 已经晚了！我得走了。

Sense.DEF: to leave the place where you are, in order to do something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Let’s go for a walk.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们去散步吧。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I need to go shopping this afternoon.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天下午我得去购物。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: My parents are going on a cruise.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我父母要去乘船游览。

Subsense.DEF: to intend to do something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’m going to tell Dad what you said.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我要把你的话说给爸爸听。

Subsense.DEF: used to talk about what will happen in the future
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He looked as if he was going to cry.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那样子好像就要哭了。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It’s going to rain later.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一会儿要下雨了。

Sense.GRAM: I always + adv/prep, not in progressive
Sense.DEF: to reach as far as a particular place or to lead to a particular place
Sense.EXAMPLE: The road goes through the middle of the forest.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条路从森林中间穿过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The belt won’t go around my waist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条腰带太短了﹐我系不上。

Sense.DEF: to change in some way, especially by becoming worse than before
Sense.TRAN: 变得﹐变成﹐变为〔尤指变坏〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company went bankrupt last year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司去年破产了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The bread’s gone mouldy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 面包已经发霉了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her hair is starting to go grey.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的头发开始变白了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He went crazy and tried to kill her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他疯了﹐想把她杀掉。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The crowd was going wild with excitement.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人群欣喜若狂。

Sense.DEF: to happen or develop in a particular way
Sense.EXAMPLE: How did your French test go?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你法语考得怎么样？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The party went well.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 派对进行得很顺利。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Everything’s going fine at the moment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 目前一切进展顺利。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I feel very encouraged by the way things are going .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 事情的发展让我很有信心。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many industries have been forced to cut jobs and it looks like the electronics industry is going the same way .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多行业被迫裁员﹐电子产业看来也是如此。

Sense.LEXUNIT: how are things going?/how’s it going?/how goes it?
Sense.DEF: used to ask someone what is happening in their life, especially used as a greeting
Sense.TRAN: 怎么样？好吗？〔尤用作问候语〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Hi Jane. How’s it going?’ ‘Fine, thanks.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “嗨﹐简﹐你好吗？”“很好﹐谢谢你。”

Sense.GRAM: I always + adv/prep, not in progressive
Sense.DEF: if something goes somewhere, that is its usual position
Sense.EXAMPLE: Where do the plates go?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些盘子放在哪里？
Sense.EXAMPLE: The book goes on the top shelf.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这本书放在书架顶层。

Sense.DEF: to be the right size, shape, or amount for a particular space
Sense.TRAN: 放进〔某个空间〕﹐装得进﹐装得下

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I don’t think all that will go in the suitcase.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得行李箱里放不下全部的东西。

Sense.DEF: to be sent or passed on

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The email went to everyone in the company.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这封电子邮件发给了公司里的每一个人。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: That letter should go by special delivery.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 那封信应该用快递寄出。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Complaints must go through the proper channels.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 必须通过正当的渠道投诉。

Sense.DEF: to be in a particular state or condition, especially a bad one
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many families are forced to go hungry .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多人家被迫忍饥挨饿。

Sense.DEF: to not be answered, noticed etc
Sense.TRAN: 没有得到回复/注意/奖励等
Sense.EXAMPLE: All my letters went unanswered.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我写的信都没有收到回复。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He hoped that his nervousness would go unnoticed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他希望没有人注意到他的紧张。

Sense.DEF: to start doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The preparations have been completed and we’re ready to go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 预备工作已经完成﹐我们可以开始了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Generally the action doesn’t get going start until after midnight.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般都是到半夜以后才开始热闹起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m going to get going on start doing the decorating next week.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我打算下个星期开始装修。

Sense.DEF: if a clock, watch, or machine goes, it moves and works as it should do
Sense.EXAMPLE: My watch isn’t going.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的手表停了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn’t get the pump going make it work .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没法让水泵工作起来。

Sense.DEF: used when you are telling someone about what movement someone or something made
Sense.EXAMPLE: She went like this with her hand.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的手这样动着。

Sense.DEF: to say something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I asked her what she meant and she just went, ‘Don’t ask!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我问她是什么意思﹐她只是说﹕“别问了！”

Sense.DEF: to make a particular sound
Sense.EXAMPLE: The balloon suddenly went bang.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 气球突然砰的一声爆了。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone not to do something, especially something that is wrong or bad
Sense.TRAN: 不要做某事〔用来告诫某人不要做某事﹐尤指错事或坏事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a secret, so don’t go telling everyone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是秘密﹐所以不要到处和别人说。

Sense.DEF: used when you are surprised or annoyed by what someone has done
Sense.TRAN: 居然做了某事﹐真的做了某事〔表示惊讶或恼火〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Kay’s gone and lost the car keys!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯竟然把车钥匙弄丢了！

Subsense.DEF: still remaining before something happens
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Only ten days to go to Christmas!
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 离圣诞节只有十天了！

Subsense.DEF: still having to be done or dealt with before you have finished
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Laura’s sat six exams and has two more to go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 劳拉已考了六门考试﹐还要考两门。

Subsense.DEF: still to travel before you reach the place you are going to
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Only another five miles left to go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只需再走五英里就到了。

Subsense.DEF: used for saying that you want to take food away from a restaurant and eat it somewhere else
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Two chicken dinners with corn to go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两份鸡块套餐加玉米﹐带走。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you do not want to think or talk about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘John and Clare having children?’ ‘Don’t go there!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “约翰和克莱尔打算要孩子？”“别说这事！”
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘What if the two of them …?’ ‘ Don’t even go there! ’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “他们俩要是……” “别说了！”

Sense.GRAM: I always + adv/prep, T not in progressive
Sense.DEF: used to talk about what something such as a story or song consists of
Sense.EXAMPLE: The argument goes like this.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 论点是这样的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We need to ‘spread a little happiness’, as the song goes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们需要“散播一些幸福”﹐就像歌词里唱的那样。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The story goes that my grandfather saved his captain’s life in battle.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 据说我祖父在战斗中救了他的船长一命。

Sense.DEF: to make a noise as a warning or signal
Sense.TRAN: 响起﹐鸣响〔作为警告或信号〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: A bell goes to mark the end of each class.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 每堂课铃响就表示下课。

Sense.DEF: used when someone has annoyed you by doing something they know you do not like
Sense.TRAN: 某人又来了〔表示某人又在做令人讨厌的事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: There you go again, jumping to conclusions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你又来了﹐草率地下结论。

Sense.DEF: to no longer exist or no longer be in the same place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Has your headache gone yet?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你头痛好了吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: The door was open and all his things had gone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 门开着﹐他所有的东西都没了。

Sense.DEF: if one of your senses such as sight, hearing etc is going, it is getting worse
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dad’s eyesight is starting to go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 爸爸的视力开始下降。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d forgotten that. My mind must be going.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把那事给忘了﹐我一定是脑子坏了。

Sense.DEF: if what someone says goes, that person is in authority and what they say should be obeyed
Sense.EXAMPLE: Phil’s in charge, and what he says goes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 菲尔是负责人﹐他说了算。

Sense.DEF: to become weak, damaged etc, or stop working properly
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bulb’s gone in the bathroom.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 卫生间的灯泡坏了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: My jeans are starting to go at the knee.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的牛仔裤膝盖处出现磨损了。

Sense.DEF: to die – use this when you want to avoid saying the word ‘die’
Sense.TRAN: 没了﹐走了〔指人死﹐委婉说法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Now that his wife’s gone, he’s all on his own.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 妻子走了﹐他孤单一人。
Sense.EXAMPLE: When I go, I’d like to have my ashes scattered at sea.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我死后想把骨灰撒到大海里。

Sense.DEF: to be spent
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know where all my money goes!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道我的钱都花到哪里去了！

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Half her salary goes on the rent.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的工资一半花在房租上。

Sense.DEF: to be sold

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A house like this would go for £250,000.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 像这样的房子可以卖25万英镑。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The jewels will go to the highest bidder.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些珠宝将卖给出价最高的人。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He bought me some CDs which were going cheap were being sold at a low price .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他给我买了一些降价的唱片。

Sense.DEF: to offer a particular amount of money for something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll give you $500 for it but I can’t go any higher than that.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我出价500美元﹐但不能给得更高了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I think we could probably go to £15,000.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我们或许可以出到15,000英镑。

Sense.DEF:
used to say that something has been sold at an
auction
Sense.TRAN: 要卖了﹐要卖了﹐卖了！〔拍卖用语〕

Sense.DEF: used to say how quickly or slowly time passes
Sense.EXAMPLE: The day seemed to go so slowly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那一天似乎过得很慢。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you are disappointed because something has stopped you doing or getting what you wanted
Sense.EXAMPLE: Well, there goes my chance of fame!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 唉﹐我的成名机会泡汤了！

Sense.DEF: to help to prove something
Sense.EXAMPLE: It just goes to show how much people judge each other by appearances.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这正好说明人们在多大程度上是以貌取人的。

Sense.DEF: to be available
Sense.EXAMPLE: Are there any jobs going at the café?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 咖啡馆里有什么工作吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll take that if it’s going spare .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个多出来的话我就拿了。

Sense.DEF: if colours, tastes, styles etc go, they look, taste etc good together
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t think pink and yellow really go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得粉红色和黄色不是很配。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Do you think this shirt will go with the skirt I bought?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你觉得这件衬衫和我买的裙子配吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Pork and apple go especially well together.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 猪肉和苹果一起吃味道特别好。

Sense.DEF: used for comparing someone or something with the average person or thing of that type
Sense.EXAMPLE: As marriages go, it certainly wasn’t dull.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 婚姻像这个样子当然不算枯燥乏味。

Sense.DEF: to try very hard to do or get something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re going all out for victory in this afternoon’s game.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们将拼尽全力赢得下午的这场比赛。

GramExa.PROPFORM: go all out to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company will be going all out to improve on last year’s sales.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司将全力以赴﹐争取创下比去年更好的销售业绩。

Sense.LEXUNIT: have nothing/not much/a lot etc going for sb/sth
Sense.DEF: used to talk about how many advantages and good qualities someone or something has
Sense.TRAN: 某人/某事物没有有利条件/有利条件不多/有利条件很多等
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a town that’s got a lot going for it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个小镇有许多吸引人的地方。

Sense.LEXUNIT: where does sb/sth go from here?
Sense.DEF: used to ask what should be done next, especially when there is a problem
Sense.TRAN: 接下去某人/某事该怎么办呢？
Sense.EXAMPLE: So where do you think we should go from here?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那么你说接下去我们该怎么办呢？

Sense.DEF: in the future – used especially in business
Sense.TRAN: 将来﹐今后〔尤为商业用语〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Going forward, we will increase our focus on customer service.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今后我们将更加注重客户服务。

Sense.DEF: to leave your job, especially because you are forced to
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was becoming an embarrassment to the government and had to go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他成了政府的耻辱﹐只好下台。
Sense.EXAMPLE: If Jill goes, who will take her place?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果吉尔走了﹐谁来接替她呢？

Sense.DEF: if something goes, someone gets rid of it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The policies will have to go if the party is to win the next election.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该党若要在下届选举中获胜﹐这些政策必须废除。
Sense.EXAMPLE: A hundred jobs are expected to go following the merger.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 合并之后100个职位就会没有了。

Sense.DEF: to make waste come out of your body
to start to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I want to learn German but I don’t know the best way to go about it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想学德语﹐但我不知道怎么样学最好。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The leaflet tells you how to go about making a will.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 小册子上写明了如何立遗嘱。

Sense.DEF: to do something in the way that you usually do
Sense.EXAMPLE: The villagers were going about their business as usual.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 村民们像往常一样各自忙碌着。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She went about her preparations in a quiet businesslike way.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她安安静静﹑认认真真地做着准备。

Sense.DEF: if a ship goes about, it turns to go in the opposite direction
to follow or chase someone or something because you want to catch them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Joe went after her to make sure she was unhurt.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔去追她﹐确保她没有受伤。

Sense.DEF: to try to get something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I can’t decide whether to go after the job or not.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我决定不了要不要去争取这份工作。

Sense.DEF: if something goes against your beliefs, principles etc, it is opposite to them
Sense.EXAMPLE: This goes against everything I’ve been brought up to believe in.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这和我从小所接受的教育背道而驰。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I often have to make decisions that go against the grain are not what I would normally choose to do .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我常常得作出违心的决定。

Sense.DEF: to do the opposite of what someone wants or advises you to do
Sense.TRAN: 违背〔某人的心愿或建议〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was scared to go against her father’s wishes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她不敢违背父亲的愿望。

Sense.DEF: if a decision, judgment etc goes against you, you do not get the result you want
Sense.EXAMPLE: His lawyer hinted that the case might go against him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的律师暗示他可能败诉。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The vote went against the government.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 投票结果对政府不利。

Sense.DEF: to start to do something, especially after planning it or asking permission to do it
Sense.TRAN: 开始〔尤指经过计划或允许后着手做〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They’ve decided to go ahead with plans to build 50 new houses on the site.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们决定开始规划﹐在这个地块上新建50栋住宅。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I went ahead and arranged the trip anyway.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不管怎么样﹐我开始安排这次旅行的事情了。

Sense.DEF: if an event or process goes ahead, it happens
Sense.EXAMPLE: A judge has ruled that the music festival can go ahead.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 法官作出裁决﹐音乐节可以举行。

Sense.DEF: used to give someone permission to do something, or let them speak before you
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Do you mind if I open the window?’ ‘No, go ahead.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “我开窗你介意吗？”“没关系﹐开吧。”
Sense.EXAMPLE: If you want to leave, go right ahead .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你想走﹐那就走吧。

Sense.DEF: to go somewhere before the other people in your group
Sense.EXAMPLE: You go ahead and we’ll catch you up later.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你先走﹐我们随后就赶上来。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He stood back to let Sue go ahead of him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他往后靠让休先走。

Sense.DEF: to start to be winning a game or competition
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dulwich went ahead after 22 minutes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 22分钟以后达利奇领先了。

Sense.DEF: if you do something as you go along, you do it without planning or preparing it
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was making the story up as he went along .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一边讲着故事﹐一边往下编。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I never had formal training, I just learned the job as I went along.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从来没有受过正规的训练﹐这个工作我是边干边学的。

Sense.DEF: to go to an event or a place where something is happening

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I might go along to the meeting tonight.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我可能会去参加今天晚上的会议。

Sense.DEF: to happen or develop in a particular way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Things seem to be going along nicely.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 好像一切进展顺利。

Sense.DEF: to agree with or support someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I would be happy to go along with the idea.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我乐意支持这个观点。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Often it was easier to go along with her rather than risk an argument.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一般都是顺着她比较好﹐免得发生争吵。

Sense.DEF: used to tell someone that you do not believe what they are saying
to behave or dress in a particular way
Sense.TRAN: 习惯于〔某种行为或穿着〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You can’t go around accusing people like that.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不能老是那样随便指责别人。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He goes around in a T-shirt even in winter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哪怕是冬天他也只穿一件T恤。

Sense.DEF: if an illness is going around, a lot of people get it
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had a bad dose of the flu virus that was going around.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 流感病毒在传播﹐他也染上了﹐而且很严重。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There are a lot of nasty bugs going around the school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学校里有很多讨厌的病菌在传播。

Sense.DEF: if news, a story, a joke etc is going around, a lot of people hear it and are talking about it
Sense.EXAMPLE: A rumour was going around that I was having an affair with my boss.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 谣言四起﹐说我和老板有染。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was a lot of gossip going around the village.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 村子里流言蜚语很多。

Sense.LEXUNIT: go around with sb/go around together
Sense.DEF: to meet someone often and spend a lot of time with them
Sense.TRAN: 常与某人外出/常一起外出
Sense.EXAMPLE: I used to go around with a bad crowd.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我过去常和一伙不三不四的人在外面鬼混。

Sense.DEF: enough for each person
Sense.EXAMPLE: Is there enough ice cream to go around?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 冰激凌够分吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: There were never enough textbooks to go around.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 教科书从来都不够用。

Sense.DEF: used to say that if someone does bad things now, bad things will happen to them in the future
if words, sounds etc go around in your head, you keep remembering them for a long time
Sense.EXAMPLE: That stupid song kept going around in my head.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那首愚蠢的歌曲一直萦绕在我的脑海里。

Sense.DEF: to attack someone or argue with someone in a noisy way
Sense.EXAMPLE: The two dogs went at each other.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两条狗在互相厮咬着。

Sense.DEF: to do something, or start to do something, with a lot of energy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mary went at the task with great enthusiasm.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽满腔热情地干起了这项工作。

Sense.DEF: to leave a place or person
Sense.EXAMPLE: Go away and leave me alone!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 走开！ 别管我！
Sense.EXAMPLE: I went away wondering if I’d said the wrong thing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我走开了﹐想着我是否说错了话。

Sense.DEF: to travel to a place and spend some time there, for example for a holiday
Sense.EXAMPLE: Are you going away this year?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你今年要外出度假吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re going away for the weekend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们要出去过周末。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s going away to college next year.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他明年要去上大学了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m going away on a business trip next week.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我下个星期要去出差。

Sense.DEF: if a problem, unpleasant feeling etc goes away, it disappears
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ignoring the crime problem won’t make it go away.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对犯罪问题视而不见并不会使其自行消失。

Sense.DEF: to return to a place that you have just come from
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think we ought to go back now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我们现在应该回去了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I felt so sick I just wanted to go back to bed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我感到很恶心﹐只想回去睡觉。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I had to go back for my passport to get my passport .
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我只好回去拿护照。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you cannot make a situation the same as it was before
Sense.EXAMPLE: I realized that once the baby was born there would be no going back.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我意识到﹐一旦有了孩子﹐就回不到从前了。

Sense.DEF: to have been made, built, or started at some time in the past
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a tradition that goes back at least 100 years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个传统至少可上溯到100年前。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The building goes back to Roman times.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个建筑物可以追溯到古罗马时代。

Sense.DEF: if people go back a particular length of time, they have known each other for that length of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Peter and I go back 25 years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我和彼得有25年的交情了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: We go back a long way we have been friends for a long time .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们是多年的老朋友了。

Sense.DEF: to think about a particular time in the past or something that someone said before
Sense.TRAN: 回想〔过去的某个时候〕﹐回到〔原来的话题〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: If you go back 20 years, most people didn’t own a computer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 20年前﹐大多数人没有电脑。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’d like to go back to the point that was made earlier.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想重申前面讲过的一点。

Sense.DEF: to not do something that you promised or agreed to do

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Delors claimed that the President had gone back on his word.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 德洛尔声称总统违背了诺言。

Sense.DEF: to start doing something again after you have stopped for a period of time
Sense.EXAMPLE: He went back to sleep.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他又入睡了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She went back to watching TV.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她又继续看电视了。

Sense.DEF: to happen or exist before something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: In some ways this program improves on what has gone before.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个程序在有些方面比以前有了改进。

Sense.DEF: if something goes before a judge, group of people in authority etc, they consider it before making a decision
Sense.TRAN: 提交给某人/某处讨论[裁决]
Sense.EXAMPLE: The case will go before the court.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个案子将在法庭审理。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The proposal is likely to go before the committee.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个提议可能会提交给委员会讨论。

Sense.DEF: to be much better, worse, more serious etc than something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: Their relationship had gone beyond friendship.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们已经超出了朋友关系。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This goes beyond all limits of acceptable behaviour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是绝对不容许的行为。

Sense.DEF: if time goes by, it passes
Sense.EXAMPLE: Things will get easier as time goes by .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 随着时间过去﹐情况会好起来的。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: As the weeks went by, I became more and more worried.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一周又一周过去了﹐我越来越担心。

GramExa.PROPFORM: hardly a day/week/month etc goes by
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Hardly a week goes by without some food scare being reported in the media.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 媒体上几乎每个星期都有食物恐慌的报道。

GramExa.GLOSS: in the past
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 在过去的日子里/岁月里/年月里等
GramExa.EXAMPLE: These herbs would have been grown for medicinal purposes in days gone by.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 以前这些香草可能是当作药材来种的。

Sense.DEF: to form an opinion about someone or something from the information or experience that you have
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can’t always go by appearances.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你不能总是以貌取人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: his past plays are anything to go by , this should be a play worth watching.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 照他以往的剧作来看﹐这出戏应该是值得一看的。

Sense.DEF: to do things according to a set of rules or laws
Sense.EXAMPLE: Only a fool goes by the rules all the time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只有傻瓜才会什么时候都循规蹈矩的。
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was no doubt that the referee had gone by the book had obeyed all the rules .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毫无疑问﹐裁判员是严格按照比赛规则来判的。

Crossrefto.REFLEX: go by the name of sth

Sense.DEF: to become lower in level, amount etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: His income went down last year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年他的收入减少了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Computers have gone down in price.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 电脑价格下跌了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Spending has gone down by 2%.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 支出减少了2%。

Sense.DEF: if something goes down, its quality or standard gets worse
Sense.EXAMPLE: This neighbourhood has really gone down in the last few years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个街区最近几年大不如前了。

Subsense.DEF: to get a particular reaction from someone
Subsense.EXAMPLE: His suggestion did not go down very well.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的建议没有得到很好的反响。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The movie went down very well in America.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部影片在美国深受好评。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The speech went down a treat with members members liked it very much .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个演说在会员中反应很好。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The idea went down like a lead balloon was not popular or successful .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个想法没有得到大家的响应。

Subsense.DEF: if food or drink goes down well, you enjoy it
Subsense.EXAMPLE: I’m not that hungry so a salad would go down nicely.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不是很饿﹐来一份色拉就够了。

Sense.SIGNPOST: GO FROM ONE PLACE TO ANOTHER
Sense.DEF: to go from one place to another, especially to a place that is further south

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re going down to Bournemouth for the weekend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们打算去伯恩茅斯度周末。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s gone down to the store to get some milk.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他去商店买牛奶了。

Sense.DEF: to go to the shops, a club etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Does anyone want to go down the pub tonight?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 今天晚上有谁想去酒吧吗？

Sense.DEF: if a ship goes down, it sinks
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ten men died when the ship went down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 船沉了﹐十人遇难。

Sense.DEF: if a plane goes down, it suddenly falls to the ground
Sense.EXAMPLE: An emergency call was received shortly before the plane went down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 坠机前不久收到过紧急呼救。

Sense.DEF: to become less swollen
Sense.EXAMPLE: The swelling will go down if you rest your foot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你让脚休息休息﹐肿胀就会消退。

Sense.DEF: if something that is filled with air goes down, air comes out and it becomes smaller and softer
Sense.EXAMPLE: Your tyre’s gone down.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你的轮胎瘪了。

Sense.DEF: to be recorded or remembered in a particular way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The talks went down as a landmark in the peace process.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这几次会谈成了和平进程中的一个里程碑。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The carnival will go down in history be remembered for many years as one of the best ever.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次狂欢节将作为有史以来最精彩的一次为后人称道。

Subsense.DEF: to lose a game, competition, or election
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The Hawkers went down 5-9.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 鹰队以5比9落败。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The government went down by 71 votes.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府以71票失利。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Liverpool went down to Juventus.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利物浦队输给了尤文图斯队。

Subsense.DEF: to move down to a lower position in an official list of teams or players
Subsense.TRAN: 〔在运动队或运动员的官方排名中〕降级﹐排名下降

GramExa.EXAMPLE: United went down to the second division.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 联队降为乙级。

Sense.DEF: if a computer goes down, it stops working for a short time
Sense.EXAMPLE: If one of the file servers goes down, you lose the whole network.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 文件服务器只要有一个瘫痪﹐整个网络就都不能用了。

Sense.DEF: if lights go down, they become less bright
Sense.EXAMPLE: The lights went down and the curtain rose on an empty stage.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 灯光暗下来﹐帷幕升起﹐露出空荡荡的舞台。

Sense.DEF: when the sun goes down, it appears to move down until you cannot see it any more
if the wind goes down, it becomes less strong
Sense.EXAMPLE: The wind had gone down but the night had turned chilly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 风小了﹐但是夜更冷了。

Sense.DEF: to be sent to prison
Sense.EXAMPLE: He went down for five years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他在牢里蹲了五年。

Sense.DEF: to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: the type of guy who knows what’s going down
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那种消息灵通的人
Sense.EXAMPLE: What’s going down?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出什么事了？

Sense.DEF: to leave Oxford or Cambridge University at the end of a period of study
Sense.TRAN: 〔从牛津大学或剑桥大学〕毕业

Sense.DEF: to touch someone’s sexual organs with the lips and tongue in order to give them sexual pleasure
to become ill, especially with an infectious disease
Sense.EXAMPLE: Half the team had gone down with flu.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 队里一半的人都患了流感。

Sense.DEF: to attack or criticize someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The dog suddenly went for me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那条狗突然向我扑来。

Sense.DEF: to try to get or win something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jackson is going for his second gold medal here.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰克逊在争取拿到在这里比赛的第二块金牌。

GramExa.GLOSS: used to encourage someone to try to achieve something
GramExa.EXAMPLE: If you really want the job, go for it!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果你真的想要那份工作﹐那就好好争取吧！

Sense.DEF: to choose something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I think I’ll go for the chocolate cake.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我就选巧克力蛋糕吧。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you would like to do or have something
Sense.EXAMPLE: A full meal for less than five bucks! I could go for that!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一顿丰盛的饭菜连五美元都不到！我要了！

Sense.DEF: to like a particular type of person or thing
Sense.TRAN: 喜欢〔某种类型的人或物〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Annie tends to go for older men.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 安妮一向喜欢年长的男人。

Sense.DEF: used to say that a statement you have just made is true about someone or something else too
Sense.EXAMPLE: Close all doors and lock them when you go out. The same goes for windows.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出去的时候要关上并锁好所有的门﹐窗子也一样。

Sense.DEF: when the sun or the moon goes in, cloud moves in front of it so that it cannot be seen
Sense.TRAN: 〔太阳或月亮〕躲进了云层﹐被云遮住

Sense.DEF: to do an examination or take part in a competition
Sense.EXAMPLE: I go in for all the competitions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我什么比赛都参加。

Sense.DEF: to do or use something often because you enjoy it or like it
Sense.EXAMPLE: I never really went in for sports.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我对体育活动从来都不是很感兴趣。

Sense.DEF: to choose something as your job
Sense.EXAMPLE: I suppose I could go in for advertising.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我想我可以从事广告行业。

Sense.DEF: to join with someone else to start a business or organization
Sense.TRAN: 和…合伙〔成立一家公司或机构〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ellie’s going in with a friend who’s just started a café.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃莉打算和一位刚开了一间咖啡馆的朋友合伙。

Sense.DEF: to start to do a particular type of job
Sense.EXAMPLE: I always wanted to go into nursing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一直想从事护理工作。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s thinking of going into business starting a business .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她在考虑去经商。

Sense.DEF: to be spent or used to get, make, or do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Years of research have gone into this book.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这本书记录了作者多年研究的心得。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A great deal of time and effort has gone into ensuring that the event runs smoothly.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 为了确保活动顺利进行﹐大量的时间和精力已投入其中。

Sense.DEF: to explain, describe, or examine something in detail
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t want to go into the matter now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我现在不想详谈这件事。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t want to go into details now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我现在不想细谈。

Sense.DEF:
to open a particular computer program,
window
, or
file
Sense.TRAN: 打开〔计算机程序﹑窗口或文档〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Go into your D drive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 打开你的D盘。

Sense.DEF: to start to be in a particular state or condition
Sense.TRAN: 开始﹐进入〔某种状态或情况〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: She went into labour at midnight and the baby was born at 8 am.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她半夜开始分娩﹐早上8点孩子出生。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company went into liquidation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这家公司停业清盘了。

Sense.DEF: if a vehicle goes into a tree, wall, or another vehicle, it hits it
Sense.EXAMPLE: His car went into a lamppost in the high street.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的车子撞上了大街的路灯柱。

Sense.DEF: if a number goes into another number, the second number can be divided by the first
Sense.EXAMPLE: 12 goes into 60 five times.

Sense.SIGNPOST: BEGIN TO MOVE IN A PARTICULAR WAY
Sense.DEF: if a vehicle goes into a particular movement, it starts to do it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The plane had gone into a steep descent.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 飞机已经开始陡降。

Sense.DEF: to leave a place, especially in order to do something
Sense.TRAN: 离开﹐走〔尤指为了做某事〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: John decided to go off on his own.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 约翰决定自己一个人走。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He went off to work as usual.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他和往常一样去上班。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Geoff went off to play golf.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 杰夫去打高尔夫球了。

Sense.DEF: to explode or fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: The bomb went off at 6.30 this morning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 炸弹在今晨6时30分爆炸。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Fireworks were going off all over the city.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 城里到处在燃放烟花。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The gun went off and the bullet went flying over his head.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 枪响了﹐子弹从他头上飞过。

Sense.DEF:
if an
alarm
goes off, it makes a noise to warn you about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The thieves ran away when the alarm went off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警报器一响﹐小偷就逃走了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve set the alarm clock to go off at 7 am.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把闹钟设在早上7点。

Sense.DEF: to stop liking something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many women go off coffee during pregnancy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多女性怀孕时不再喝咖啡。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ve gone off cooking lately.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我最近对做饭不感兴趣了。

Sense.DEF: if a machine or piece of equipment goes off, it stops working
Sense.EXAMPLE: The central heating goes off at 9 o’clock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 中央供暖系统9点钟停开。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Suddenly, all the lights went off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 霎时间﹐所有的灯都熄灭了。

Sense.DEF: to happen in a particular way
Sense.EXAMPLE: The party went off very well.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 派对开得很顺利。

Sense.DEF: to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was a blazing row going off next door.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 隔壁吵得正凶。

Sense.DEF: if food goes off, it becomes too bad to eat
Sense.EXAMPLE: The milk’s gone off.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 牛奶坏了。

Sense.DEF: to go to sleep
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d just gone off to sleep when the phone rang.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我刚入睡﹐电话铃响了。

Sense.DEF: to get worse
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s a singer whose talent has gone off in recent years.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是一名近年来才华已尽的歌手。

Sense.DEF: to criticize or speak to someone in a very angry way
to leave your usual sexual partner in order to have a relationship with someone else
Sense.TRAN: 〔抛弃配偶〕移情别恋于…﹐跟…私奔
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s gone off with her husband’s best friend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她跟她丈夫最好的朋友跑了。

Sense.DEF: to take something away from a place without having permission
Sense.EXAMPLE: Who’s gone off with my pen?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 谁拿走了我的钢笔？

Subsense.DEF: to continue doing something or being in a situation

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He went on working until he was 91.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一直工作到91岁。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: One of the actors was unwell and couldn’t go on with the performance.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 其中一名演员身体不适﹐不能继续演出。

Subsense.EXAMPLE: I can’t go on like this for much longer.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 像这样子我支撑不了多久。

Subsense.DEF: to continue without stopping
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The noise goes on 24 hours a day.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 噪音一天24个小时不消停。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The screaming went on and on continued for a long time .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尖叫声持续了很久。

Sense.DEF: to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don’t know what’s going on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道发生了什么事情。
Sense.EXAMPLE: What were the children doing while all this was going on?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一切发生时孩子们都在干什么？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Like all good resorts, there is plenty going on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 和所有的旅游胜地一样﹐这里也是非常热闹。

Sense.DEF: to do something after you have finished doing something else

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She went on to become a successful surgeon.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她后来成了一名成功的外科医生。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Go on to the next question when you’ve finished.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 做完后接着做下一道题。

Sense.DEF: to continue talking, especially after stopping or changing to a different subject
Sense.EXAMPLE: Go on, I’m listening.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 接着说呀﹐我在听呢。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘But,’ he went on, ‘we have to deal with the problems we’re facing.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “但是﹐”他接着说道﹐“我们必须解决现在所面临的问题。”

GramExa.EXAMPLE: After a short pause Maria went on with her story.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽亚停顿了一会儿﹐又接着讲她的故事。

Subsense.DEF: used to encourage someone to do something
Subsense.TRAN: 来吧〔用于鼓励某人做某事〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Go on, have another piece of cake.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 来吧﹐再吃一块蛋糕。

Subsense.DEF: used when you are agreeing to do something or giving permission for something
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘Are you sure you won’t have another drink?’ ‘Oh, go on then.’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你真的不再来一杯吗？”“噢﹐那就再来一杯吧。”
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘Can I go outside, Dad?’ ‘Yeah, go on then.’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “我能出去吗﹐爸爸？”“行﹐你去吧。”

Subsense.DEF: used to tell someone that you do not believe them

Sense.DEF: to base an opinion or judgment on something
Sense.TRAN: 以某事为根据〔作出判断〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Police haven’t much to go on in their hunt for the killer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 警方手中追查凶手的线索不多。

Sense.DEF: if a machine or piece of equipment goes on, it starts to work
Sense.EXAMPLE: The heat goes on automatically at 6 o’clock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 6点开始自动供暖。

Sense.DEF: to pass
Sense.EXAMPLE: As time went on, I grew fond of him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 随着时间的推移﹐我慢慢开始喜欢他了。

Sense.DEF: the way someone goes on is the way they behave
Sense.EXAMPLE: The way she’s going on, she’ll have a nervous breakdown.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她这样下去会精神崩溃的。

Sense.DEF: to be nearly a particular time, age, number etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nancy must be going on for 60.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 南希肯定快60岁了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s one of those wise teenagers who’s 16 going on 70 she behaves as though she is older than she is .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是那种少年老成的聪明女孩﹐16岁的人好像有70岁的见识。

Sense.DEF: to go somewhere before the other people you are with
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bill went on in the car and I followed on foot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 比尔坐车先走﹐我步行跟在后面。

Sense.DEF: to talk too much
Sense.TRAN: 没完没了地说﹐唠叨个没完
Sense.EXAMPLE: I really like Clare but she does go on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我很喜欢克莱尔﹐不过她太爱唠叨了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I got tired of him going on about all his problems.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没完没了讲他的各种问题﹐我都听烦了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He just went on and on about his new girlfriend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他一个劲地讲他的新女友。

Sense.DEF: to continue to criticize someone or ask them to do something in a way that annoys them
Sense.EXAMPLE: The way she went on, you would have thought it was all my fault.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她如此数落指责﹐你会觉得一切都是我的错。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Stop going on at me!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 别再数落我了！

GramExa.PROPFORM: go on at sb to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: My wife’s always going on at me to dress better.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我妻子老是唠叨﹐要我穿得好些。

GramExa.PROPFORM: go on at sb about sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’s always going on at me about fixing the door.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他老是缠着要我修门。

Sense.DEF: to develop or make progress

Sense.LEXUNIT: to be going on with/to go on with
Sense.DEF: if you have enough of something to be going on with, you have enough for now
Sense.EXAMPLE: Have you got enough money to be going on with?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你现在钱够用吗？

Sense.DEF: to leave your house, especially in order to enjoy yourself
Sense.EXAMPLE: Are you going out tonight?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你今晚要出去吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We went out for a meal and then on to a movie.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们出去吃了饭﹐然后又看了一场电影。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Liam goes out drinking every Friday.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利亚姆每个星期五都出去喝酒。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can I go out to play now?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我现在可以出去玩吗？

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You should go out and get some fresh air.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你应该出去呼吸一下新鲜空气。

Sense.DEF: to have a romantic relationship with someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: They’ve been going out for two years now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们谈恋爱已经两年了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Tina used to go out with my brother.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 蒂娜以前和我哥哥谈过恋爱。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: How long have you been going out together?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你们俩交往有多长时间了？

Sense.DEF: to stop burning or shining
Sense.EXAMPLE: Suddenly the candle went out.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 蜡烛突然熄灭了。

Sense.DEF: to be broadcast on television or radio
Sense.TRAN: 〔在电视或无线电中〕广播﹐播放﹐播出
Sense.EXAMPLE: The programme goes out live at 5 o’clock on Mondays.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个节目每周一5点现场直播。

Sense.DEF: to be sent
Sense.EXAMPLE: A copy of the instructions should go out with the equipment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 设备中应该附一份说明书。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The magazine goes out to all members at the end of the month.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 杂志会于月底寄给所有的会员。

Sense.DEF: to stop playing in a competition because you have lost a game
Sense.EXAMPLE: He went out in the first round.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他第一轮就被淘汰了。

Sense.DEF: to travel to another country in order to live and work there

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They are looking for nurses to go out to Saudi Arabia.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们在寻找护理人员到沙特阿拉伯去。

Sense.DEF: to stop being fashionable or used
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hats like that went out years ago.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那样的帽子早就不流行了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: This kind of entertainment went out with the ark is very old-fashioned .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种娱乐老掉牙了。

Sense.DEF:
when the
tide
goes out, the sea moves away from the land
if news or a message goes out, it is officially announced to everyone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The appeal went out for food and medicines.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 呼吁号召公众提供食物和药品。

Sense.LEXUNIT: your heart/thoughts go out to sb
Sense.DEF: used to say that you feel sympathy for someone and are thinking about them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Our hearts go out to the victim’s family.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们非常同情受害者的家人。

Sense.DEF: to end
Sense.EXAMPLE: March went out with high winds and rain.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 3月在劲风暴雨中结束。

Sense.DEF: to think very carefully about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had gone over and over what happened in my mind.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 发生的这一切﹐我在心里想了又想。

Sense.DEF: to search or examine something very carefully
Sense.EXAMPLE: In the competition, the judge goes over each dog and assesses it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 比赛中﹐评委仔细检查每一条狗﹐给它们评分。

Sense.DEF: to repeat something in order to explain it or make sure it is correct
Sense.EXAMPLE: Once again I went over exactly what I needed to say.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把我要说的话又一字不差地重复了一遍。

Sense.DEF: to clean something
if something goes over well, people like it
Sense.EXAMPLE: That kind of salesman talk doesn’t go over very well with the scientists.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那种推销的说辞﹐科学家是不会相信的。

Sense.DEF: to change to a different place or person for the next part of a television or radio programme
Sense.TRAN: 〔电视或广播节目〕切换到﹐转到
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re going over to the White House for an important announcement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们把镜头切换到白宫﹐收看一则重要公告的发布。

Sense.DEF: to change to a different way of doing things
Sense.EXAMPLE: They went over to a computerized records system.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们改用计算机化的档案系统。

Sense.DEF: to change to a different political party or religion
Sense.TRAN: 转投〔别的政党〕﹔改信〔另一宗教〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: the Labour MP who went over to the Conservatives last year
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年投奔保守党的那位工党议员

Sense.DEF: to experience a difficult or unpleasant situation, feeling etc
Sense.TRAN: 经受某事﹐经历某事〔指困境﹑痛苦等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: When you’re going through a crisis, it often helps to talk to someone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 遇到危机的时候﹐找个人说说往往很有帮助。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s going through a divorce at the moment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 目前他正经历离婚的变故。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It is devastating for a parent to watch a child go through misery.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看着孩子经受痛苦会让父母心碎。

Sense.DEF: to experience a particular process
Sense.EXAMPLE: Candidates must go through a process of selection.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 候选人必须经过筛选。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Caterpillars go through several stages of growth.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 毛虫要经历好几个生长阶段。

Sense.DEF: to use up money or a supply of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We went through five pints of milk last week.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们上个星期用了五品脱牛奶。

Sense.DEF: if a law goes through, or goes through Parliament, it is officially accepted
if a deal or agreement goes through, it is officially accepted and agreed
Sense.EXAMPLE: He accepted the offer and the deal went through.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他接受了这个报价﹐生意成交了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The sale of the land went through.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 土地买卖成交了。

Sense.DEF: to practise something, for example a performance
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s go through the whole thing again, from the beginning.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们从头开始再排练一遍吧。

Sense.DEF: to search something in order to find something in particular
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dave went through his pockets looking for the keys.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 戴夫翻遍了衣袋找钥匙。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Customs officers went through all my bags.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 海关官员检查了我所有的旅行袋。

Sense.DEF: to read or discuss something in order to make sure it is correct
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll go through the details later on.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们稍后再讨论细节。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do you want me to go through this and check your spellings?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你要我把这通读一遍﹐帮你检查拼写吗？

Sense.DEF: to do something you had promised or planned to do, even though it causes problems or you are no longer sure you want to do it
Sense.EXAMPLE: He bravely went through with the wedding ceremony even though he was in a lot of pain.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他虽然疼痛万分﹐但还是毅力惊人地坚持到婚礼结束。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had no choice but to go through with it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没有别的选择﹐只有坚持到底。

Sense.DEF: to begin to experience or do something, or begin to be in a particular state
Sense.TRAN: 面临﹐开始做〔某事〕﹔进入〔某种状态〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: I lay down and went to sleep.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我躺下来睡觉了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Britain and Germany went to war in 1939.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 1939年﹐英国和德国开战。

Sense.DEF: to be given to someone or something
Sense.EXAMPLE: All the money raised will go to local charities.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 募集的所有钱款都将捐给当地慈善机构。

Sense.DEF: if two things go together, they exist together or are connected in some way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Alcohol abuse and eating disorders often go together.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 酗酒往往伴随着饮食紊乱。

Sense.DEF: if two people are going together, they are having a romantic relationship
if money goes towards something, it is used to pay part of the cost of that thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: The money will go towards a new hospice.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这笔钱将用于支付新建安养院的部分费用。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: All money raised will go towards renovating the building.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 所筹资金都将用于支付修缮大楼的部分款项。

Sense.DEF: if a business goes under, it has to stop operating because of financial problems
Sense.EXAMPLE: More than 7,000 businesses have gone under in the last three months.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在过去三个月里有7,000多家公司倒闭。

Sense.DEF: to sink beneath the surface of water
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Titanic finally went under.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “泰坦尼克”号最后还是沉没了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She went under, coughing and spluttering.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她身子往下沉﹐边咳嗽边呼呼地吐气。

Sense.DEF: to increase in price, amount, level etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔价格﹑数量等〕上升﹐增加﹔〔水平〕提高
Sense.EXAMPLE: Train fares have gone up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 火车票涨价了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Blood-sugar levels go up as you digest food.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 消化食物的时候血糖会升高。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Unemployment in the country has gone up by a million.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 国内的失业人数增加了100万。

GramExa.PROPFORM: go up from sth to sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Spending on research went up from $426 million to $461 million.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 研究费用从4.26亿美元增加到了4.61亿美元。

Sense.DEF: if a building or sign goes up, it is built or fixed into place
Sense.TRAN: 〔建筑〕建造起来﹔〔标牌〕竖立起来
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was a lovely place before all these new houses went up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在这些新房子盖起来之前﹐这儿原来是一个很漂亮的地方。

Sense.DEF: to explode, or be destroyed in a fire
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had left the gas on and the whole kitchen went up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没有关煤气﹐整个厨房都烧起来了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole building went up in flames .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 整座大楼燃起了熊熊大火。

Sense.DEF:
if a shout or a
cheer
goes up, people start to shout or
cheer

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A great cheer went up from the audience.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 观众爆发出热烈的欢呼声。

Sense.DEF: to go from one place to another, especially to a place that is further north, or to a town or city from a smaller place
Sense.TRAN: 去﹐到〔尤指从南到北〕﹔进城

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re going up to Scotland next weekend.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们下个周末要去苏格兰。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He went up to the farm to get some eggs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他上农场去拿些鸡蛋。

Sense.DEF: if lights go up, they become brighter
Sense.EXAMPLE: when the lights went up at the end of the performance
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 演出结束后灯光亮起的时候

Sense.DEF: to begin studying at a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge University
Sense.TRAN: 上大学〔尤指牛津或剑桥大学〕

Sense.DEF: to be included as part of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The house goes with the job.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这份工作提供住房。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He had fame, money, and everything that goes with it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他有名有利﹐还有名利所带来的一切。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Responsibility goes with becoming a father.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 当了父亲也就有了责任。

Sense.DEF: to often exist with something else or be related to something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ill health often goes with poverty.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 疾病经常与贫穷相伴。

Sense.DEF: to have a romantic relationship with someone
to have sex with someone
to accept someone’s idea or plan
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s go with John’s original proposal.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们听从约翰原来的提议吧。

Sense.DEF: to not have something that you usually have
Sense.EXAMPLE: I like to give the children what they want even if I have to go without.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们想要的﹐我宁可自己不要也要给他们。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It is possible to go without food for a few days.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 几天不吃东西是可以的。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something is so clearly true that it does not need to be said
Sense.EXAMPLE: The Internet, too, it goes without saying, is a good source of information.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不用说﹐因特网也是一个很好的信息来源。

Sense.DEF: an attempt to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘I can’t open this drawer.’ ‘Here, let me have a go .’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “我打不开这个抽屉。”“来﹐让我试试看。”
Sense.EXAMPLE: On the tour, everyone can have a go at making a pot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次去参观﹐每个人都可以试着做一个陶罐。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’d thought about it for some time and decided to give it a go try to do something .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事我考虑了一段时间﹐决定尝试一下。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had a good go tried hard at cleaning the silver.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我费了老大的劲清洁银器。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Ruby blew out all her candles at one go.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 鲁比一口气吹灭了所有的蜡烛。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m not sure it will work but it’s worth a go .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我不知道这是否可行﹐但是值得一试。

Sense.DEF: someone’s turn in a game or someone’s turn to use something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Whose go is it?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 轮到谁了？
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s your go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 轮到你了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can I have a go on your guitar?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我能玩玩你的吉他吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t I get a go ?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 就没有我的机会吗？

Sense.DEF: to make something succeed, especially a business or marriage
Sense.TRAN: 使某事〔尤指生意或婚姻〕成功
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nikki was determined to make a go of the business.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尼基下决心一定要把公司办成功。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many businesses are struggling hard to make a go of it .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多公司都在努力打拼﹐想要干出一番名堂。

Sense.DEF: used for saying how much it costs to do something or buy something
Sense.EXAMPLE: At £3 a go, the cards are not cheap.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这卡片3英镑一张﹐不便宜。

Subsense.DEF: if you have something on the go, you have started it and are busy doing it
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Even with three top films on the go, Michelle is reluctant to talk about herself.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 虽然在忙着拍三部大片﹐米歇尔还是不愿意谈论自己。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: He has at least two other projects on the go .
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他至少还有两个其他的项目在忙。

Subsense.DEF: very busy doing a lot of things
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Children are always on the go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小孩子总是闲不住。

Sense.DEF: used to say that things are working correctly or that you have permission to do something
Sense.TRAN: 某事顺利进行﹔某事获得同意
Sense.EXAMPLE: The trip to London is a go.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伦敦之行敲定了。

Sense.DEF: used to say that something is not allowed or will not happen
Sense.TRAN: 某事是不允许的﹔某事是不可能的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hotel is no go for dogs.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宾馆里不允许带狗进来。

Sense.DEF: it is very busy
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s all go around here.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这里很忙。
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s all go in the commercial property market.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 商业地产市场非常活跃。

Subsense.DEF: to criticize someone
Subsense.EXAMPLE: You’re always having a go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你老是在说人家的不是。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Will you stop having a go at me!
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你别说我了好不好！

GramExa.PROPFORM: have a go at sb for/about sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mum had a go at me for not doing my homework.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 妈妈因为我没有做家庭作业而数落我。

Subsense.DEF: to attack someone
Subsense.EXAMPLE: A whole gang of yobs were standing around, just waiting to have a go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一帮野小子站在那里﹐就等着寻衅打架。

Subsense.DEF: to try to catch someone who you see doing something wrong, rather than waiting for the police
Subsense.TRAN: 〔不等警察到来〕企图自行抓坏人
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The public should not be encouraged to have a go.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不应鼓励公众自行抓坏人。

Sense.DEF: energy and a desire to do things
Sense.EXAMPLE: There’s plenty of go in him yet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他依然精力充沛。

Sense.DEF: very fashionable
to make someone do something by annoying or encouraging them until they do it

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Kathy goaded him into telling her what he had done.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯茜逼着他把自己所干的事告诉了她。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They goaded him on with insults.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们辱骂他﹐逼着他继续干。

Sense.DEF: to push animals ahead of you with a sharp stick
something that forces someone to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The offer of economic aid was a goad to political change.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 提供经济援助是政治改革的推动力。

Sense.DEF: a sharp stick for making animals move forward
to give or be given permission to start doing something
Sense.TRAN: 给予（某人）许可/得到准许
Sense.EXAMPLE: The company has been given the go-ahead to build a new supermarket.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司得到批准﹐可以新建一个超级市场。

Sense.DEF: using new methods or ideas and therefore likely to succeed
Sense.EXAMPLE: a go-ahead company
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 开拓型的公司

Sense.DEF: something that you hope to achieve in the future
Sense.EXAMPLE: Your goal as a parent is to help your child become an independent adult.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 身为父母﹐你的目标就是要培养孩子成为独立的成年人。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday British English, people often talk about what someone is aiming to do rather than talk about someone’s goal .
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英国英语中﹐谈论某人的目标时﹐常说be aiming to do﹐而不说goal
F2NBox.BADEXA: His goal is to set up his own business.
F2NBox.GOODEXA: ➔ He’s aiming to set up his own business.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的目标是自己开公司。

Sense.DEF:
the area between two posts where the ball must go in order to score in games such as football or
hockey

GramExa.GLOSS: be the goalkeeper

Sense.DEF: the action of making the ball go into a goal, or the score gained by doing this
Sense.EXAMPLE: I scored the first goal .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我踢进了第一个球。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: My main goal was to get the team to the finals.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的首要目标是让球队进入决赛。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: what they eventually and most importantly hope to achieve
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The ultimate goal is a freer, more democratic society.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 最终的目标是建立更加自由﹑更加民主的社会。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: that you need to achieve very soon
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Our immediate goal is to cut costs.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们眼前的目标是要降低成本。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: that you hope to achieve after a long time
that you hope to achieve after a short time
an aim shared by more than one person or organization
an aim that will be difficult to achieve

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She had one goal in life: to accumulate a huge fortune.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她平生有一个目标﹕要积累起巨额财富。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We are all working towards similar goals.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们都为类似的目标在努力。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They’re hoping to reach their goal of raising £10,000 for charity.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们希望能实现募集一万英镑善款的目标。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: decide what you or someone else should try to achieve

Sense.DEF: a goalkeeper
the player in a sports team whose job is to try to stop the ball going into the goal
a kick in football taken by a goalkeeper after the attacking team has kicked the ball over the goal line
a goalless match is one in which no goals are scored

a line at either end of the playing area in sports such as football or
hockey
, along which the goal is placed

the area directly in front of a
goal

one of the two posts, with a bar along the top or across the middle, that form the
goal
in games such as football and
hockey
to change the rules, limits etc for something while someone is trying to do something, making it more difficult for them – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 改变规则〔以增大难度﹐含贬义〕

Sense.DEF:
a
goalkeeper
an animal that has horns on top of its head and long hair under its chin, and can climb steep hills and rocks. Goats live wild in the mountains or are kept as farm animals.

PIC.HEADING: GOATS 山羊
PIC.PICCONTENT: horn 角；goat 山羊；billy goat 公山羊

Sense.DEF: to make someone extremely annoyed
an unpleasant old man, especially one who annoys women in a sexual way
Sense.TRAN: 令人生厌的老头﹔〔尤指〕老色鬼﹐老色狼

Sense.DEF: to behave in a silly way

a small pointed
beard
on the end of a man’s chin
someone who looks after a group of goats
an impolite word for someone’s mouth
Sense.EXAMPLE: Jean told him to shut his gob .
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 琼叫他闭嘴。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She’s always stuffing her gob with food.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她总在往嘴里塞吃的。

Sense.DEF: a mass of something wet and sticky

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There’s a gob of gum on my chair.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我的椅子上有一团口香糖。

Sense.DEF: a large amount of something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: gobs of money
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多钱

Sense.DEF: to blow a small amount of liquid out of your mouth
a small piece of something, especially food
Sense.TRAN: 一小片﹐一小块〔尤指食物〕

Sense.DEF:
to eat something very quickly, especially in an impolite or
greedy
way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Don’t gobble your food!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 吃东西别狼吞虎咽的！
Sense.EXAMPLE: She gobbled down her lunch.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她几口就吃完了午饭。

Sense.DEF:
to make a sound like a
turkey
if one company gobbles up a smaller company, it buys it and takes control of it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Air France gobbled up its main French rivals, Air Inter and UTA.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 法国航空公司吞并了它在法国的两个主要竞争对手——法国国内航空公司和法国联合航空运输公司。

Sense.DEF: to quickly use a lot of a supply of something such as money or land
Sense.TRAN: 很快消耗掉〔钱款﹑土地等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Inflation has gobbled up our wage increases.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 通货膨胀抵消了我们工资的增长。

Sense.DEF:
to eat something very quickly, especially in an impolite or
greedy
way
Sense.EXAMPLE: We gobbled up all of the cake in one evening.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们一个晚上就把蛋糕全部吃光了。

Sense.DEF: complicated language, especially in an official or technical document, that is impossible or difficult to understand – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 〔公文或科技资料中〕晦涩的语言﹐难懂的文字〔含贬义〕

Sense.DEF:
a male
turkey
someone who takes messages from one person or group to another because the two sides cannot meet or do not want to meet

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A UN representative will act as a go-between for leaders of the two countries.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一名联合国代表将在两国领导人之间担任中间人。

Sense.DEF: a cup made of glass or metal, with a base and a stem but no handle
Sense.TRAN: 〔玻璃或金属制的〕无柄高脚酒杯

Sense.DEF: a small ugly creature in children’s stories that likes to trick people
Sense.TRAN: 〔童话中喜欢捉 弄人的〕小妖精

Sense.DEF: very surprised or shocked
Sense.TRAN: 非常吃惊的﹐目瞪口呆的

Sense.DEF:
another spelling of
go-kart

the spirit or
being
who Christians, Jews, Muslims etc pray to, and who they believe created the universe
Sense.EXAMPLE: Prayer is a way of talking to God.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 祈祷是同上帝交流的一种方式。
Sense.HINTTRAN: In this sense, God is written with a capital letter and without ‘the’. God意为“上帝”时首字母大写﹐不用the: We asked God (NOT 不说 the God) to help us. 我们请求上帝帮助我们。Expressions containing the word God such as oh my God are common in spoken English but can offend religious people. 在英语口语中﹐像oh my God这样含God的短语很常见﹐但会冒犯笃信宗教的人士。

Sense.DEF:
a male spirit or
being
who is believed by some religions to control the world or part of it, or who represents a particular quality
Sense.TRAN: 〔主宰世界或象征某种品质的〕神﹐男神

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Mars, the god of war
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 战神玛尔斯

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Zeus was one of the most well-known Greek gods.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 宙斯是最广为人知的希腊神之一。

Sense.DEF: someone who thinks they are perfect or extremely attractive – used to show disapproval
Sense.TRAN: 上帝赐给某人/某物的礼物〔指某人自以为很完美或非常有魅力﹐含贬义〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Paul thinks he’s God’s gift to women.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 保罗以为他就是上帝赐给女人的礼物。

Sense.DEF: someone who is admired very much
Sense.EXAMPLE: To his fans he is a god.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对他的粉丝来说﹐他就是神。

Sense.DEF: something which you give too much importance or respect to
Sense.TRAN: 受到过分关注[推崇]的事物
Sense.EXAMPLE: Money became his god.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 钱成了他的命。

Subsense.DEF: the force that some people believe controls their lives, bringing them good or bad luck
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The gods are against us.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老天爷在跟我们作对。

Subsense.DEF: the seats high up and at the back of a theatre
Subsense.TRAN: 〔剧院里的〕顶层楼座﹐最高楼座

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize what you are saying, when you are surprised, annoyed, or amused
Sense.TRAN: 天啊〔惊讶﹑恼怒或开心时用于加强语气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Oh God, how embarrassing!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 天啊﹐多难堪啊！

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize something you are saying when you are annoyed
Sense.TRAN: 看在上帝的份上〔恼怒时用于加强语气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: For God’s sake, shut up!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 看在上帝的份上﹐别说了！

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that you promise, hope etc that something is true
Sense.TRAN: 我对天发誓/衷心希望/祈求上帝
Sense.EXAMPLE: I hope to God nothing goes wrong.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我祈求上帝保佑一切顺利。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you very much hope that something will not happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: God forbid that this should ever happen again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 上帝保佑再也不要发生这种事了。

Subsense.DEF: used to show that you are annoyed because you do not know something, or because you think that something is unreasonable

GramExa.EXAMPLE: God knows what she’s doing in there.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 天晓得她在那儿干什么。

Subsense.DEF: used to emphasize what you are saying
Subsense.EXAMPLE: God knows, it hasn’t been easy.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老天爷为证﹐这事不容易啊。

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize a question when you are angry or surprised
Sense.TRAN: 究竟什么/如何/哪里/谁〔生气或惊讶时用于加强语气〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Where in God’s name have you been?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你到底去了什么地方？

Sense.DEF: used to warn someone that something bad will happen
Sense.TRAN: 上帝保佑你/他等〔用于警告某人会有不好的事发生〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: God help you if you spill anything on the carpet.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你要是把什么东西洒到了地毯上﹐那就求上帝保佑吧。

Sense.DEF: said humorously when you think that something bad is going to happen
Sense.TRAN: 愿上帝保佑我们〔坏事将要发生时的幽默说法〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Simon’s doing the cooking.’ ‘God help us!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “西蒙在做饭。”“愿上帝保佑我们！”

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that you are not lying or joking
Sense.TRAN: 向上帝保证〔强调某事绝对是真的〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Honest to God, I didn’t tell her!
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我向上帝保证﹐我没有告诉她！

Sense.DEF: used to say that you hope there will be no problems
Sense.TRAN: 如上帝许可〔用来表示希望一切顺利〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’ll be moving next month, God willing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 顺利的话﹐我们下个月搬家。

Sense.DEF: used to say that you hope someone will be safe and happy, especially when you are saying goodbye
Sense.TRAN: 上帝保佑你〔尤用于道别时〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Good night and God bless.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 晚安﹐上帝保佑你。

Sense.DEF: used when you are becoming annoyed
Sense.TRAN: 上帝给我力量！〔用于开始感到恼怒时〕

Sense.DEF: said when someone is explaining that something very good happened to them at a time when they thought that their situation was very bad
Sense.TRAN: 真是有上帝啊！〔逆境中遇到好事时说的话〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: In walked four gorgeous, blond Swedish boys, and I thought, ‘There is a God!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 进来的是四个英俊的金发瑞典少年﹐当时我就想: “真是有上帝啊！”

Sense.DEF: used to show respect when speaking about someone who is dead
Sense.TRAN: 愿上帝让他/她安息〔用于谈及死者时表示敬意〕

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize how determined or surprised you are
Sense.TRAN: 老天作证〔表示决心或惊讶时用来加强语气〕

Crossrefto.REFLEX: there but for the grace of God
in the lap of the gods

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Do you believe in God?
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 你信上帝吗？

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They prayed to God for forgiveness.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们祈求上帝的宽恕。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: show love and respect for God

Collocate.EXAMPLE: About one-third of the population has no belief in God.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 大约有三分之一的人不信神。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: what God wants to happen
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He believed it was God’s will that they should suffer.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他相信让他们受苦是神的旨意。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He swore by Almighty God to tell the truth.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他以全能的上帝的名义起誓说真话。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: what God says

Sense.DEF: very bad or unpleasant. Some Christian people find this word offensive
Sense.TRAN: 非常糟糕的〔有些基督徒认为该词有冒犯性〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: What’s that god-awful smell?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那是什么臭味呀？

Sense.DEF:
the child that a
godparent
promises to help and to teach Christian values to. This promise is made at a
baptism
ceremony.
a word used to express annoyance, anger etc. Some Christian people consider this word offensive.
Sense.TRAN: 见鬼﹐该死的〔表示恼火﹑生气等﹔有些基督徒认为该词有冒犯性〕

Sense.DEF: a word used to show that you are angry or annoyed, considered offensive by some Christians
Sense.TRAN: 该死的〔表示生气或恼火﹔有些基督徒认为该词有冒犯性〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Where’s the goddamn key?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该死的钥匙在哪儿？

RunOn.EXAMPLE: I just did something so goddamned stupid.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 我刚做了一件愚蠢透顶的事。

Sense.DEF: a female godchild

a female
being
who is believed to control the world or part of it, or represents a particular quality
Sense.TRAN: 〔主宰世界或象征某种品质的〕女神
Sense.EXAMPLE: Aphrodite, goddess of love

Sense.DEF: an attractive female film star

a male
godparent

the head of a criminal organization such as the

Sense.DEF: someone who began or developed something such as a type of music

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 嘻哈乐教父阿弗里卡·班巴塔

Sense.DEF: leading a good life and following the rules of the Christian religion
a godforsaken place is far away from where people live and contains nothing interesting, attractive, or cheerful

Sense.EXAMPLE: How can you stand living in this godforsaken town?

Sense.DEF: received from God
Sense.EXAMPLE: She has a God-given talent for singing.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她有唱歌的天赋。

GramExa.GLOSS: the right to do something without asking anyone else’s opinion
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The protesters have no God-given right to disrupt the life of the city.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 抗议者没有理所当然的权利扰乱这个城市的生活。

Sense.DEF: a word that Christians use to mean the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, who they consider to be one God in three parts
Sense.TRAN: 圣主﹐上帝〔指圣父﹑圣子和圣灵三位一体的上帝〕

Sense.DEF: not respecting God or not believing in a god
having a quality like God or a god

Sense.DEF: obeying God and leading a good life

a female
godparent

someone who promises at a

the
national anthem the official national song
of the UK. The title of the song changes to God Save the King when the
monarch
is a king.
Sense.TRAN: 《天佑女王》〔英国国歌﹐如果是国王在位﹐歌名则改为《天佑国王》〕

Sense.DEF: something good that happens to you when you really need it

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The hot weather has been a godsend for ice-cream sellers.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 炎热的天气对于冰激凌售卖者来说是天赐良机。

Sense.DEF:
a male
godchild
used to wish someone good luck, especially before a journey

Sense.DEF: an insulting way of describing Christians who try to persuade other people to become Christians
Sense.TRAN: 上帝使团〔侮辱性用语﹐指劝人入教的基督徒〕

Sense.DEF: a woman who often has sex with different men

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她是个破鞋。

Sense.DEF: used after words such as party, church, and theatre to form nouns that refer to people who regularly go to parties, church etc

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 常去看电影的人

Sense.DEF: someone who carries messages etc for their employer
someone who is likely to be successful because they are very determined and have a lot of energy
to look at something with your eyes wide open in surprise or shock
Sense.TRAN: 〔由于惊讶或震惊〕瞪大眼睛看

GramExa.EXAMPLE: They were goggling at us as if we were freaks.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们瞪眼看着我们﹐好像我们是怪物似的。

Sense.DEF: with your eyes wide open and looking directly at something, especially in surprise or shock

a pair of
glasses
made of glass or plastic with a rubber or plastic edge that fit against your skin and protect your eyes

PIC.HEADING: GOGGLES 护目镜
PIC.PICCONTENT: safety goggles 安全护目镜；ski goggles 滑雪镜；swimming goggles 游泳镜

Sense.DEF: a go-go period of time is one in which prices and the amount workers are paid increase very quickly

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济腾飞的20世纪80年代

Sense.DEF:
go-go
stocks
increase in value very quickly in a short period of time, but involve a lot of risk

a woman who dances with sexy movements in a bar or

Sense.TRAN: 歌歌舞舞女〔酒吧或夜总会跳色情舞蹈的女子〕

Sense.DEF: the difficulty or speed with which something is done

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m getting the work done, but it’s slow going.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这事我正在做﹐但是进度很慢。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We climbed the mountain in three hours, which wasn’t bad going.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在三小时内爬上了山﹐这样的速度不错了。

Sense.DEF: the act of leaving a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: His going will be no great loss to the company.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的离去对公司来说并不算多大的损失。

Sense.DEF: if a book, play etc is heavy going, it is boring and difficult to understand
if you suggest doing something while the going’s good, you think it should be done before it becomes difficult or impossible
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s leave while the going’s good.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们趁现在这个机会快走吧。

Sense.LEXUNIT: when the going gets tough, the tough get going
Sense.DEF: when the conditions become difficult, strong people begin to do something in a determined way
Sense.TRAN: 时势造英雄﹐环境造就人

Sense.DEF: the condition of the ground, especially for a horse race
the usual amount you pay or receive as payment for something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Thirty dollars an hour is the going rate for a math tutor.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 数学家教现在的收费行情是30美元1小时。

Sense.DEF: the biggest, best etc of a particular thing
Sense.TRAN: 现今最大的/最好的/最美好的某物
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s some of the best beer going.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是现在最好的一种啤酒。

Sense.DEF: available

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你工作的地方有职位空缺吗？

Sense.LEXUNIT: have a lot going for you

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别这么沮丧﹐你有很多有利条件。

Sense.DEF: a business which is making a profit and is expected to continue to do so
used after words such as cinema and theatre to form adjectives that describe people who regularly go to the cinema, theatre etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: the cinema-going public
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 常去看电影的民众

Sense.DEF: a thorough examination of something to make sure it is all right

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 媒体对他的私生活刨根究底。

Sense.DEF: to improve the condition of something, for example by cleaning it thoroughly
Sense.TRAN: 改善某物﹔彻底清理某物
Sense.EXAMPLE: You ought to give the place a going-over with the Hoover once in a while.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你应该隔一阵子就用吸尘器把家里收拾收拾。

Sense.DEF: to hit someone and hurt them
activities or events that are strange or interesting, and often illegal
Sense.TRAN: 〔内容怪异或有趣﹑常常违反法律的〕活动﹐勾当

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学校里的一些现象让她感到震惊。

Sense.DEF: a red fruit, grown especially in China, that is often dried before being eaten
a small vehicle with an open frame and four wheels, used in races
a valuable soft yellow metal that is used to make coins, jewellery etc. It is a chemical element: symbol Au

GramExa.GLOSS: a measurement used to show how pure gold is

Sense.DEF: coins, jewellery etc made of gold

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她披金戴银地来参加派对。

Sense.DEF: the colour of gold

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 房间的装修用了金色和蓝色。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Gold looks good on people with dark hair.

Sense.DEF:
a
gold medal

Sense.DEF: having the colour of gold

Sense.DEF: someone who stays away from their work, especially by pretending that they are ill
